'''''AIP Conference Proceedings''''' is a [[serial (publishing)|serial]] published by the [[American Institute of Physics]] since 1970. It publishes the [[proceedings]] from various [[Academic conference|conference]]s of [[professional society|physics societies]]. [[Alison Waldron]] is the current Acquisitions Editor for ''AIP Conference Proceedings''. In addition to the series' own [[ISSN]], each volumes receives its own [[ISBN]].<ref> {{cite web |title=About the Proceedings |url=http://proceedings.aip.org/about/about_the_proceedings |publisher=[[American Institute of Physics]] |accessdate=2011-08-02 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110717004252/http://proceedings.aip.org/about/about_the_proceedings| archivedate= 17 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
''AIP Conference Proceedings'' publishes more than 100 volumes per year,<ref name=IF> {{cite web | title=Impact Factors & ISSNs for AIP Journals | publisher=[[American Institute of Physics]] | url=http://librarians.aip.org/titles.html | accessdate=2011-07-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110724230742/http://librarians.aip.org/titles.html| archivedate= 24 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> with back-file coverage to 1970 which encompasses 1,330 proceedings volumes and 100,000 published papers.<ref name=prm> {{Cite press release |date=June 2, 2011 |title=100,000th Paper Marks Significant Milestone for AIP Conference Proceedings Series |url=http://www.aip.org/press_release/aip_conference_proceedings_100000_paper.html |publisher=[[American Institute of Physics]] |accessdate=2011-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819091500/http://www.aip.org/press_release/aip_conference_proceedings_100000_paper.html |archivedate=August 19, 2011 }}</ref>
==Scope== In 2010 broad subject coverage included [[Particle accelerator|accelerators]], [[biophysics]], [[plasma physics]], [[geophysics]], [[polymer science]], [[optics]], [[lasers]], [[nanotechnology]], [[materials science]], [[astronomy]], [[astrophysics]], [[mathematical physics]], [[nuclear physics|nuclear]] and [[particle physics]], [[statistical physics]], [[atomic physics|atomic]] and [[molecular physics]].<ref name=cover> {{cite web | title=Publication overall description | publisher=[[American Institute of Physics]] | url=http://scitation.aip.org/journals/doc/APCPCS-home/brochure.pdf | accessdate=2011-07-26 }}</ref>

The '''Afghan War documents leak''', also called the '''Afghan War Diary''', is the disclosure of a collection of internal [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. military]] logs of the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]], which were published by [[WikiLeaks]] on {{Nowrap|25 July}} 2010. The logs consist of over 91,000{{cite news|title=Afghan War diary|url=https://wikileaks.org/afg/|accessdate=May 28, 2015|publisher=WikiLeaks|date=July 25, 2010}} Afghan War documents, covering the period between January 2004 and December 2009. Most of the documents are classified [[Classified information in the United States#Secret|secret]].{{cite news |title=Piecing Together the Reports, and Deciding What to Publish |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/26/world/26editors-note.htm |accessdate=26 July 2010}} As of 28 July 2010, only 75,000 of the documents have been released to the public, a move which WikiLeaks says is "part of a harm minimization process demanded by [the] source".{{cite web |url=https://wikileaks.org/wiki/Afghan_War_Diary,_2004-2010 |title=Afghan War Diary, 2004–2010 |publisher=WikiLeaks |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65mzn4HnD?url=http://wikileaks.org/wiki/Afghan_War_Diary,_2004-2010 |archivedate=28 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |date=25 July 2010 |accessdate=28 February 2012 |df= }} Prior to releasing the initial 75,000 documents, WikiLeaks made the logs available to ''[[The Guardian]]'',{{cite news|title=Afghanistan: The war logs |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/series/afghanistan-the-war-logs |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=3 August 2010 |location=London |date=4 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730093531/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/series/afghanistan-the-war-logs |archivedate=30 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} ''[[The New York Times]]''{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/world/war-logs.html |work=The New York Times |first1=Mark |last1=Mazzetti |first2=Jane |last2=Perlez |first3=Eric |last3=Schmitt |first4=Andrew W. |last4=Lehren |title=The War Logs |date=25 July 2010}} and ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' in its German and English online edition,{{cite web|author=Politik |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,708311,00.html |title=Enthüllung brisanter Kriegsdokumente – Die Afghanistan-Protokolle |publisher=Spiegel.de |date=2010-07-25 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,708314,00.html "The Afghanistan Protocol – Explosive Leaks Provide Image of War from Those Fighting It"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727001057/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C708314%2C00.html |date=July 27, 2010}} which published reports per previous agreement on that same day, 25 July 2010.{{cite news |title=Afghanistan war logs: How the Guardian got the story |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/afghanistan-war-logs-explained-video |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog+world/series/afghanistan-the-war-logs |location=London |title=Datablog + Afghanistan: The war logs |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729141045/http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/datablog%2Bworld/series/afghanistan-the-war-logs |archivedate=2010-07-29 |accessdate=20 May 2013}} The leak, which is considered to be one of the largest in [[Military history of the United States|U.S. military history]],{{cite web |url=http://www.onthemedia.org/transcripts/2010/07/30/02 |title=From One Transparency Advocate to Another |publisher=Onthemedia.org |date=2010-07-30 |accessdate=2013-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628181904/http://www.onthemedia.org/transcripts/2010/07/30/02 |archivedate=2011-06-28 |df= }} revealed information on the deaths of civilians, increased [[Taliban]] attacks, and involvement by [[Pakistan]] and [[Iran]] in the [[Taliban insurgency|insurgency]].{{cite news |title=Afghan war log leak: Around the web |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/07/26/f-wikileaks-afghanistan-docs-roundup.html |accessdate=23 July 2010}} WikiLeaks says it does not know the source of the leaked data.{{cite news |title= WikiLeaks: We don't know source of leaked data |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[Google]] |date=28 July 2010 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gKu1DQoewmBy2do5ctRqUX5efGBAD9H82DRO0 |accessdate=28 July 2010}} The three outlets which had received the documents in advance, ''The New York Times'', ''The Guardian'', and ''Der Spiegel'', have all concluded that they are genuine when compared with independent reports.{{cite news |first1=Matthias |last1=Gebauer |first2=John |last2=Goetz |first3=Hans |last3=Hoyng |first4=Susanne |last4=Koelbl |first5=Marcel |last5=Rosenbach |first6=Gregor Peter |last6=Schmitz |title=Explosive Leaks Provide Image of War from Those Fighting It |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,708314,00.html |accessdate=27 July 2010}} ''The New York Times'' described the leak as "a six-year archive of classified military documents [that] offers an unvarnished and grim picture of the Afghan war". ''The Guardian'' called the material "one of the biggest leaks in U.S. military history ... a devastating portrait of the failing [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]], revealing how coalition forces have killed hundreds of civilians in unreported incidents, Taliban attacks have soared and [[NATO]] commanders fear neighbouring Pakistan and Iran are fuelling the insurgency". ''Der Spiegel'' wrote that "the editors in chief of ''Spiegel'', ''The New York Times'' and the ''Guardian'' were 'unanimous in their belief that there is a justified [[public interest]] in the material'." Some time after the first dissemination by WikiLeaks, the U.S. Justice Department considered using the U.S. [[Espionage Act of 1917]] to prevent WikiLeaks from posting the remaining 15,000 secret war documents it claimed to possess.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/17/AR2010081705225.html |work=The Washington Post |title=The Justice Department weighs a criminal case against WikiLeaks |date=18 August 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2010/08/18/us-to-use-espionage-act-against-wikileaks.html |title=US to use Espionage Act against WikiLeaks |publisher=News.oneindia.in |date=2010-08-18 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/espionage-act-of-1917 |title=Espionage Act of 1917 |publisher=Answers.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}} ==Background== {{Main|WikiLeaks}} In June 2010, ''Guardian'' journalist [[Nick Davies]] and WikiLeaks founder [[Julian Assange]] established that the U.S. Army had built a huge database with six years of sensitive military intelligence material, to which many thousands of U.S. soldiers had access and some of them had been able to download copies, and WikiLeaks had one copy which it proposed to publish online, via a series of uncensorable global servers.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/02/afghan-war-logs-wikileaks |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=David |last=Leigh |title=Afghan War Logs: what did we learn? |date=2 August 2010}} Some of the soldiers were not supposed to have any access as they were not involved in those operations. WikiLeaks describes itself as "a multi-jurisdictional public service designed to protect whistleblowers, journalists and activists who have sensitive materials to communicate to the public".{{cite web|title=WikiLeaks:About |url=https://wikileaks.org/wiki/WikiLeaks:About |publisher=[[WikiLeaks]] |accessdate=29 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730023422/https://wikileaks.org/wiki/Wikileaks%3AAbout |archivedate=30 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In an interview with the UK's [[Channel 4]], Assange said that "we have a stated commitment to a particular kind of process and objective, and that commitment is to get censored material out and never to take it down". He contrasted the group with other media outlets by saying that "other journalists try to verify sources. We don't do that, we verify documents. We don't care where it came from." He denied that the group has an inherent bias against the Afghanistan War, saying that "We don't have a view about whether the war should continue or stop – we do have a view that it should be prosecuted as humanely as possible." However, he also said that he believes the leaked information will turn world public opinion to think more negatively of the war. An Obama administration statement disputed the self-reported status of WikiLeaks, stating that it "is not an objective news outlet but rather an organization that opposes U.S. policy in Afghanistan".{{cite news |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2010/07/26/114847.html |title=Washington condemns leak of Afghan war files |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729135943/http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2010/07/26/114847.html|archivedate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Journalist Will Heaven of ''The Daily Telegraph'' has said that WikiLeaks was not politically neutral when it fed its information to the left-leaning newspapers ''The Guardian'', ''The New York Times'', and ''Der Spiegel'' instead of releasing the data openly. He said that the selectivity of the leak "contravene[d] its own mission statement – that [[crowdsourcing]] and open data are paramount".{{cite news |first=Will |last=Heaven |title=Wikileaks is a website without an agenda, says Julian Assange. So what the hell is it playing at? |url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/willheaven/100048486/wikileaks-is-a-website-without-an-agenda-says-julian-assuage-so-what-the-hell-is-it-playing-at/ |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |location=London}}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}{{cbignore}} The ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' has referred to Assange's statements "This material shines light on the everyday brutality and squalor of war" and "The archive will change [[public opinion]] and it will change the opinion of people in positions of political and diplomatic influence" as evidence that he has an anti-war mission.{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Lilley |title=Wikileaks founder on anti-war mission |url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/world/2010/07/27/14845941.html |newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010}} ==Issues raised== ===Allegations of foreign support for the Taliban=== ====Pakistan==== According to ''Der Spiegel'', "the documents clearly show that the Pakistani intelligence agency [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (usually known as the ISI) is the most important accomplice the Taliban has outside of Afghanistan".{{cite news |first1=Matthias |last1=Gebauer |first2=John |last2=Goetz |first3=Hans |last3=Hoyng |first4=Susanne |last4=Koelbl |first5=Marcel |last5=Rosenbach |first6=Gregor Peter |last6=Schmitz |title=Explosive Leaks Provide Image of War from Those Fighting It: The Secret Enemy in Pakistan |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,708314-5,00.html |accessdate=26 July 2010}} ''The New York Times'' was especially alarmed by the level of collusion with the Taliban, having concluded that Pakistan "allows representatives of its spy service to meet directly with the Taliban in secret strategy sessions to organize networks of militant groups that fight against American soldiers in Afghanistan, and even hatch plots to assassinate Afghan leaders". ''The Guardian'', however, did not think there was "a convincing smoking gun" for complicity between [[Inter-Services Intelligence|Pakistan intelligence services]] and the Taliban.{{cite news |first1=Kimberly |last1=Dozier |title=Leaked tales from the front lines paint dark portrait of Afghanistan |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/us-condemns-massive-military-leak-exposing-dark-side-of-afghan-war/article1651348/ |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=Toronto}} In particular, the leaks discuss an alleged incident in which Pakistan's former ISI spy chief [[Hamid Gul]] met with Afghan insurgents in January 2009, occurring right after alleged Pakistani al-Qaeda figure Osama al-Kini's death by a CIA drone attack. "The meeting attendees were saddened by the news of Zamarai's death and discussed plans to complete Zamarai's last mission by facilitating the movement of a suicide vehicle-borne improvised explosive device from Pakistan to Afghanistan through the Khan Pass", leaked reports said. ''The New York Times'' stated that it could not confirm whether or not that the attack ever took place. The initial web article in ''The New York Times'' on the subject, appearing 25 July was written by [[Mark Mazzetti]], [[Jane Perlez]], [[Eric P. Schmitt|Eric Schmitt]], and Andrew Lehren, and titled "Pakistan Spy Service Aids Insurgents, Reports Assert". It was the lead article in the 26 July print edition of the ''Times''.{{cite news |first1=Mark |last1=Mazzetti |first2=Jane |last2=Perlez |first3=Eric |last3=Schmitt |first4=Andrew W. |last4=Lehren |title=Pakistan Spy Service Aids Insurgents, Reports Assert |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/world/war-logs.html |accessdate=26 July 2010}} The article provided a wide range of excerpts from the paper, at some points focusing on coalition successes, and at other times excerpting sections that highlighted coalition failures. Many of the excerpts illustrated American frustration with local involvement, quoting the sources, noting that "glimpses of what appear to be Pakistani skullduggery contrast sharply with the frequently rosy public pronouncements of Pakistan as an ally by American officials". ''The Guardian'' had a very different take. Its Sunday, 25 July 2010 article by [[Declan Walsh (journalist)|Declan Walsh]] states:
But for all their eye-popping details, the intelligence files, which are mostly collated by junior officers relying on informants and Afghan officials, fail to provide a convincing smoking gun for ISI complicity. Most of the reports are vague, filled with incongruent detail, or crudely fabricated. The same characters – famous Taliban commanders, well-known ISI officials – and scenarios repeatedly pop up. And few of the events predicted in the reports subsequently occurred. A retired senior American officer said ground-level reports were considered to be a mixture of "rumours, bullshit and second-hand information" and were weeded out as they passed up the chain of command.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/pakistan-isi-accused-taliban-afghanistan |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Declan |last=Walsh |title=Afghanistan war logs: Clandestine aid for Taliban bears Pakistan's fingerprints |date=25 July 2010}}
The [[Obama administration]], in response to the leaks, re-expressed their long-held doubts about links between Pakistan intelligence agents and Afghan insurgents. An anonymous official said to [[Al Arabiya]], "I don't think anyone who follows this issue will find it surprising that there are concerns about ISI and safe havens in Pakistan". ====Iran==== Evidence that [[Iran]] provided extensive assistance to the [[Taliban]] was also revealed. Coming from sources such as Afghan spies and paid informants, Iranian involvement in Afghanistan steadily widened from 2004 to today and constituted armaments, money, and physical deployment of anti-NATO militants.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Tisdall |title=Afghanistan war logs: Iran's covert operations in Afghanistan |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/iran-backing-taliban-alqaida-afghanistan |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} The [[government of Iran]] denies supporting the militants. ====North Korea==== The documents, wrote journalist [[Jeff Stein (author)|Jeff Stein]] of the ''[[Washington Post]]'', stated that [[Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin|Hezb-e-Islami party]] leader [[Gulbuddin Hekmatyar]] and Amin al-Haq, a financial advisor to [[Osama Bin Laden]], both flew to [[North Korea]] on 19 November 2005, and purchased remote-controlled rockets to be used against American and coalition aircraft. Stein cautioned that he has found no corroborating reports of North Korean involvement in Taliban armaments dealing.{{cite news |first=Jeff |last=Stein |authorlink=Jeff Stein (author) |title=Wikileaks documents: N. Korea sold missiles to al-Qaeda, Taliban |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/spy-talk/2010/07/wiki_n_korea_sold_rockets_to_a.html |work=The Washington Post |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728034058/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/spy-talk/2010/07/wiki_n_korea_sold_rockets_to_a.html |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df= }} ===Civilian casualties=== {{further|Civilian casualties of the War in Afghanistan (2001–present)}} Hundreds of civilians have been wounded or killed by coalition forces in several instances that were not previously revealed.{{cite news |first1=Nick |last1=Davies |authorlink1=Nick Davies |first2=David |last2=Leigh |authorlink2=David Leigh (journalist) |title=Afghanistan war logs: Massive leak of secret files exposes truth of occupation |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/afghanistan-war-logs-military-leaks |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}}{{cite news |first1=David |last1=Leigh |first2=Rob |last2=Evans |title=Afghanistan war logs: Civilians caught in firing line of British troops |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/british-troops-afghan-civilian-shootings?intcmp=239 |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}}{{cite news |first=Stephen |last=Foley |title=Whistleblower's leaked US files reveal state of Afghan war |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/whistleblowers-leaked-us-files-reveal-state-of-afghan-war-2035547.html |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} The press listed several examples of such previously unreported incidents of civilian injuries and deaths.{{cite news |first=David |last=Leigh |title=Afghanistan war logs: Secret CIA paramilitaries' role in civilian deaths |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/afghanistan-civilian-deaths-rules-engagement |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] of ''The Guardian'' wrote: {{blockquote|They range from the shootings of individual innocents to the often massive loss of life from air strikes, which eventually led President [[Hamid Karzai]] to protest publicly that the US was treating Afghan lives as "cheap". The logs refer to sums paid of 100,000 [[Afghan afghani|Afghani]] per corpse, equivalent to about [[£]]1,500.}} In one incident, a U.S. patrol machine-gunned a bus, wounding or killing 15 of its passengers.{{cite news |first1=Katherine |last1=Faulkner |title=British fury as Wikileaks publishes the 90,000 top secret files that expose the horrific civilian cost of Afghan war |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1297644/Wikileaks-publishes-90-000-documents-Afghan-war.html |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} On 4 March 2007, in the [[2007 Shinwar shooting|Shinwar shooting]], [[U.S. Marines]] opened fire on civilians after witnessing a [[suicide bombing]] and supposedly coming under small arms fire. ''The Guardian'' reported their actions:
The marines made a frenzied escape [from the scene of the bombing], opening fire with automatic weapons as they tore down a six-mile stretch of highway, hitting almost anyone in their way – teenage girls in the fields, motorists in their cars, old men as they walked along the road. Nineteen unarmed civilians were killed and 50 wounded.
The military report of the incident (written by the same soldiers involved in it) later failed to make any reference to the deaths and injuries and none of the soldiers involved were charged or disciplined.{{cite news |first=Declan |last=Walsh |title=Afghanistan war logs: How US marines sanitised record of bloodbath |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/26/afghanistan-war-logs-us-marines |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} On 21 March 2007, CIA paramilitaries fired on a civilian man who was running from them. The man, Shum Khan, was deaf and mute and did not hear their warnings.{{cite news |title=Afghanistan war logs: "Other government agency" shoots deaf mute |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/afghanistan/warlogs/0B4F081B-E448-4722-9E52-EA10DE4E0153 |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} In 2007, documents detail how U.S. special forces dropped six 2,000 lb bombs on a compound where they believed a "high-value individual" was hiding, after "ensuring there were no innocent Afghans in the surrounding area". A senior U.S. commander reported that 150 Taliban had been killed. Locals, however, reported that up to 300 civilians had died.{{cite news |url=http://blog.dawn.com/2010/07/27/the-isi-america%E2%80%99s-favourite-scapegoat/ |title=The ISI: America's favourite scapegoat |newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802004823/http://blog.dawn.com/2010/07/27/the-isi-america%E2%80%99s-favourite-scapegoat/# |archivedate=2010-08-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On 16 August 2007, [[Nangar Khel incident|Polish troops mortared the village of Nangar Khel]], killing five people – including a woman and her baby – in what ''The Guardian'' described as an apparent revenge attack shortly after experiencing an [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] explosion.{{cite news |title=Afghanistan war logs: Polish attack on village kills five, wounds several, including pregnant woman at wedding party |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/afghanistan/warlogs/5EA14116-2B6B-470C-8DB4-2912DDF197BF |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} According to ''The Guardian'', the logs also detail "how the Taliban have caused growing carnage with a massive escalation of their roadside bombing campaign, which has killed more than 2,000 civilians to date". ===Friendly-fire casualties=== A significant number of documents describe unreported or previously misleading [[friendly fire]] incidents between Afghan police and army forces, coalition forces, and the U.S. military. A document dating 3 September 2006 suggests that four Canadian soldiers died in the [[Panjwaye District]] of Afghanistan during [[Operation Medusa]], when an American jet dropped a bomb on a building they occupied during the second day of the operation. Seven other Canadian soldiers and one civilian were also reported wounded in the attack.{{cite news|title=Military rejects WikiLeaks friendly fire report |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/07/26/wikileak-afghanistan-canada-soldiers.html |accessdate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729015117/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/07/26/wikileak-afghanistan-canada-soldiers.html |archivedate=July 29, 2010}} At the time, the Canadian military reported that the deaths and injuries were caused by a firefight with the Taliban, which it still insists. Michel Drapeau, a former colonel with the Canadian Forces, commented that the document is disturbing, due to it differing from the military's report at the time of the soldiers' deaths, which could make the document incorrect. The Canadian military insists it had not been misleading facts about deaths of Canadian soldiers.{{cite news |title=Leaked file suggests 4 Canadians killed by friendly fire |publisher=[[CTV News]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20100726/wikileaks-nato-concerns-100726/ |accessdate=27 July 2010}} Former [[Chief of the Defence Staff (Canada)|Chief of the Defence Staff]] [[Rick Hillier]] also rejects the document and maintains the deaths were due to enemy fire,{{cite news |title=Hillier slams WikiLeaks 'friendly fire' report |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/07/27/hillier-wikileaks-friendly-fire-allegation.html |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728230041/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/07/27/hillier-wikileaks-friendly-fire-allegation.html|archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} as do some of the deceased soldiers' families.{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20100727/soldiers-wikileaks-100727/ |title=WikiLeaks report untrue: father of slain soldier |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=27 July 2010 |publisher=[[CTV News]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729193026/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20100727/soldiers-wikileaks-100727/|archivedate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} A document from 11 June 2007 details an incident where [[Task Force 373]] engaged in a firefight with what were believed to be insurgents. An airstrike was called in, which killed seven Afghan police officers, and injured four others. [[Nangarhar Province]] governor [[Gul Agha Sherzai]] had labelled the incident a misunderstanding.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/afghanistan/warlogs/35C17E54-C611-4F39-8C39-553F5927AC96 |title=Afghanistan war logs: US special forces gunship shoots 15 police |work=The Guardian |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=25 July 2010 |location=London}}{{cite news |title=Bin Laden among latest Wikileaks Afghan revelations |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-10774419 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728023030/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-10774419|archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Less than 48 hours after the documents were leaked, the UK's [[Ministry of Defense (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defense]] released a statement{{cite web |url=http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/MilitaryOperations/SoldierFrom36EngineerRegimentKilledInAfghanistan.htm |title=Soldier from 36 Engineer Regiment killed in Afghanistan |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719194033/http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/MilitaryOperations/SoldierFrom36EngineerRegimentKilledInAfghanistan.htm|archivedate=19 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} announcing a new [[friendly fire]] death in Afghanistan. {{blockquote|The Ministry of Defense must confirm that the death of this soldier is being investigated as a suspected friendly fire incident.}} The Ministry had previously announced{{cite web |url=http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/MilitaryOperations/ModConfirmsfriendlyFireInvestigation.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504182941/http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/MilitaryOperations/ModConfirmsfriendlyFireInvestigation.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-05-04 |title=MOD confirms 'Friendly Fire' investigation |publisher=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] |date=16 January 2009 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |df= }} an investigation into a friendly fire incident in 2009 in [[Helmand]] province. ===Role of al-Qaeda=== The war logs made clear that [[suicide bombing]], generally carried out by non-Afghan foreign fighters, was increasing and claim that they were nurtured by [[al-Qaeda]] and [[Osama bin Laden]], whose influence was pervasive and possibly growing. A report generated September 2004 stated that terrorists had been assigned by Bin Laden to conduct a suicidal attack against the Afghan president Hamid Karzai, during a press conference or a meeting held. Another report, in September 2008, spoke of coordinated, multinational al-Qaeda attack planning. More suicide bombings allegedly were planned with al-Qaeda's Afghan allies, such as the Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin militia led by the notorious warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. Numerous reports linked Bin Laden and al-Qaeda to insurgent activities. In one report, al-Qaeda was claimed to be involved in a plan to manufacture [[chemical weapons]] payloads for [[rocket-propelled grenade]]s.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/26/afghanistan-war-logs-osama-bin-laden |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Simon |last=Tisdall |title=Afghanistan war logs reveal hand of Osama bin Laden |date=26 July 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/afghanistan/warlogs/772DE21C-2219-0B3F-9F29789162135989 |location=London |work=The Guardian |title=Afghanistan war logs: Al-Qaida alleged to be involved in rocket smuggling |date=25 July 2010}} ===Role of special ops greater than previously revealed=== Government accounts of coalition activity were, according to ''The Guardian'', sometimes "misleading". The British paper cited as an example a press statement that concealed the fact that the real reason for a coalition presence in a particular area was because a group known as [[Task Force 373]] was on a mission to kill or capture [[Abu Laith al-Libi]].{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Davies |title=Afghanistan war logs: Task Force 373 – special forces hunting top Taliban |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/25/task-force-373-secret-afghanistan-taliban |accessdate=26 July 2010 |location=London}} ''The New York Times'' reported that the United States had given Afghans credit for missions actually carried out by Special Operations commandos.''The New York Times'' said "over all, the documents do not contradict official accounts of the war. But in some cases the documents show that the American military made misleading public statements".{{cite news |title=Inside the Fog of War: Reports From the Ground in Afghanistan |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/26/world/asia/26warlogs.html |accessdate=26 July 2010}} The records log 144 incidents regarding Task Force 373 and involving Afghan civilian casualties, including 195 deaths. ===Detainment facilities and procedures=== {{Further|Bagram torture and prisoner abuse}} The leak lends hard numbers such as prisoner head counts and prisoner transfer dates to existing journalistic concerns around certain detainment facilities, such as [[Bagram Theater Internment Facility]], and their practices.{{cite news |first=David |last=Rose |title=Why Bagram is Guantanamo's evil twin and Britain's dirty secret |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/moslive/article-1232665/Why-Bagram-Guantanamos-evil-twin-Britains-dirty-secret.html |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=9 December 2009 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |location=London}} ===Taliban use of heat-seeking missiles=== ''The New York Times'' reported that the documents reveal the Taliban have used [[heat-seeking missile]]s to [[List of Coalition aircraft losses in Afghanistan|down coalition aircraft]]. The U.S. military had not previously acknowledged that the Taliban possessed these weapons. ===Informants named=== Some, including [[Barack Obama]] and [[Hamid Karzai]], raised concerns that the detailed logs had exposed the names of Afghan informants, thereby endangering their lives.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/01/afghan-war-wikileaks-press-comment|title=WikiLeaks' Afghan story raises dilemma over safety of sources – The WikiLeaks log showed the failures of the Afghan war – but the media moved on, overwhelmed by the weight of material|last=Preston|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter Preston|date=1 August 2010|publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]]|accessdate=24 August 2010 |location=London|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100804210852/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2010/aug/01/afghan-war-wikileaks-press-comment|archivedate=4 August 2010 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url =https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/aug/09/afghanistan-war-logs-readers-editor |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Chris |last=Elliott |title=Open door |date=9 August 2010}} Partially in response to this criticism, [[Julian Assange]] claimed that [[WikiLeaks]] had sought the help of [[Executive Office of the President|the White House]], via ''[[The New York Times]]'', in redacting the names of 'innocent' people but that this request had been denied.{{cite news|last1=Dishneau|first1=David|title=Informant says WikiLeaks suspect had civilian help |work=Washington Times |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/jul/31/informant-wikileaks-suspect-had-civilian-help/|agency=Associated Press|date=31 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100803095256/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jMcOwbxcWePUbiw1xIxXaes1qn3AD9HA9VB00|archivedate=3 August 2010}}{{cite news|last1=Goodman|first1=Amy|title=Julian Assange Responds to Increasing US Government Attacks on WikiLeaks|url=https://www.democracynow.org/2010/8/3/julian_assange_responds_to_increasing_us|work=Democracy Now!|date=3 August 2010}} However, ''New York Times'' reporter, [[Eric Schmitt]], who was acting as an intermediary between WikiLeaks and the White House, told the ''[[Associated Press]]'' that, "I certainly didn't consider this a serious and realistic offer to the White House to vet any of the documents before they were to be posted, and I think it's ridiculous that Assange is portraying it that way now." WikiLeaks spokesperson, [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg|Daniel Schmitt]], told ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' that they had sought the help of the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] in reviewing a further 15,000 documents for redactions before releasing them but Marine Colonel David Lapan, a senior spokesperson for the Department of Defense, said they had not been contacted by WikiLeaks.{{cite news|last1=Shenon|first1=Philip|title=WikiLeaks' Cry for Help|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2010/08/03/wikileaks-julian-assange-admiral-mike-mullen-afghan-war-logs-daniel-schmitt-germany-joint-chiefs-of-staff-pentagon-marine-colonel-david-lapin.html|work=The Daily Beast|date=4 August 2010}} [[Julian Assange]] later told an [[Associated Press]] reporter in Sweden that WikiLeaks had contacted the Department of Defense's chief legal counsel, via its lawyers—a claim that was denied by Bryan Whitman, a spokesman for [[Defense Secretary]], [[Robert Gates]].{{cite news|last1=Hosenball|first1=Mark|title=Pentagon Says WikiLeaks Is Fibbing|url=http://www.newsweek.com/pentagon-says-wikileaks-fibbing-217194|work=Newsweek|date=18 August 2010}} However, a letter, written by [[General Counsel of the Department of Defense]], [[Jeh Charles Johnson]], in reply to WikiLeaks' attorney, Timothy Matusheski, was later released (either by the Department of Defense or WikiLeaks{{cite web|last=Greenwald |first=Glenn |url=http://www.salon.com/news/opinion/glenn_greenwald/2010/08/20/wikileaks/index.html |title=Why won't the Pentagon help WikiLeaks redact documents? |publisher=Salon.com |date=2010-08-20 |accessdate=2013-07-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110327003330/http://www.salon.com/news/opinion/glenn_greenwald/2010/08/20/wikileaks/index.html|archive-date=2011-03-27|dead-url=yes}}), in which Johnson identified the names of Afghan informants as 'sensitive items' but, in keeping with Bryan Whitman's later public statement, stated that: {{Quote|text=the Department of Defense will {{underline|not}} negotiate some "minimized" or "sanitized" version of a release by WikiLeaks of additional U.S. Government classified documents. The Department demands that {{underline|nothing}} further be released by WikiLeaks, that {{underline|all}} of the U.S. Government classified documents that WikiLeaks has obtained be returned immediately, and that WikiLeaks remove and destroy all of these records from its databases. |author=[[Jeh Charles Johnson]] |source={{cite web|last1=American Forces Press Service|title=Pentagon Releases Letter Sent to Purported WikiLeaks Attorney|url=http://archive.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=60494|publisher=U.S. Department of Defense|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214033459/http://openanthropology.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/gc-letter.pdf|archivedate=14 December 2010|date=18 August 2010}} }} Asked by ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' why WikiLeaks did not review all of the documents and make redactions where necessary before their release, [[Daniel Domscheit-Berg|Daniel Schmitt]] replied that the volume of documents made it impossible. Speaking to ''[[Channel 4 News]]'', official spokesman for [[the Taliban]], [[Zabihullah Mujahid]], said that the Taliban would study the released documents in order to discover and punish informants. {{Quote|text=We knew about the spies and people who collaborate with U.S. forces. We will investigate through our own secret service whether the people mentioned are really spies working for the U.S. If they are U.S. spies, then we know how to punish them. |author=[[Zabihullah Mujahid]] |source={{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Jonathan|title=Taliban hunt Wikileaks outed Afghan informers|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/uk/taliban+hunt+wikileaks+outed+afghan+informers/3727667.html|work=Channel 4 News|date=30 July 2010}} }} When Assange was questioned about this statement by [[Amy Goodman]] in a ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' interview, he responded, {{Quote|text=I reviewed the statement of someone that a London paper claimed to be speaking for some part of the Taliban. Remember, the Taliban is actually not a homogenous group. And the statement, as far as such things go, was fairly reasonable, which is that they would not trust these documents; they would use their own intelligence organization's investigations to understand whether those people were defectors or collaborators, and if so, after their investigations, then they would receive appropriate punishment. Now, of course, that is — you know, that image is disturbing, but that is what happens in war, that spies or traitors are investigated. |author=[[Julian Assange]] |source= }} Former WikiLeaks volunteer, [[Smári McCarthy]], told ''[[The Independent]]'', 'there were serious disagreements over the decision not to redact the names of Afghan civilians'.{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Jerome|title=Secret war at the heart of Wikileaks|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/online/secret-war-at-the-heart-of-wikileaks-2115637.html|work=The Independent|date=24 October 2010}} [[The Guardian|''Guardian'']] journalist, [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]], claimed that [[Julian Assange]] initially refused to redact the names of informants.{{cite news|last1=Ellison|first1=Sarah|title=The Man Who Spilled the Secrets|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2011/02/the-guardian-201102|work=Vanity Fair|date=6 January 2011}} In his book, co-authored with [[Luke Harding]], ''[[WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy]]'', Leigh claimed Assange to have said in relation to whether the names should be redacted, "Well, they're informants. So, if they get killed, they've got it coming to them. They deserve it."{{cite book|last1=Leigh|first1=David|last2=Harding|first2=Luke|title=WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy|date=2011|publisher=Guardian Books|location=London, UK|isbn=978-0-85265-239-8}} In response to the book's publication, WikiLeaks posted on [[Twitter]]: "''The Guardian'' book serialization contains malicious libels. We will be taking action."{{cite tweet |author=WikiLeaks |author-link=WikiLeaks |user=wikileaks |number=32867678527950848 |date=2011-02-02 |title=The Guardian book serialization contains malicious libels. We will be taking action. |access-date=2017-09-13}} When [[Douglas Murray (author)|Douglas Murray]] relayed these comments in a debate, Assange interjected "We are in the process of suing ''The Guardian'' in relation to that comment."{{cite news|title=This house believes whistleblowers make the world a safer place: Part II|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/the-staggers/2011/04/assange-murray-speech|work=New Statesman|date=10 April 2011}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' claimed the following day that they had 'not received any notification of such action from WikiLeaks or its lawyers', two months after the publication of the book.{{cite news|last1=Addley|first1=Esther|title=Julian Assange claims WikiLeaks is more accountable than governments|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/apr/09/julian-assange-wikileaks-public-debate|work=The Guardian|date=10 April 2011}} ===Psychological warfare=== Evidence within the documents suggest that the U.S. military has been paying Afghan radio and print media to run favorable stories,{{cite news | first1=John | last1=Cook | url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ynews/20100727/wl_ynews/ynews_wl3247 | title=Leaked files indicate U.S. pays Afghan media to run friendly stories | newspaper=[[Yahoo]] | date=27 July 2010 | accessdate=4 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100730083935/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ynews/20100727/wl_ynews/ynews_wl3247| archivedate= 30 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} with two prominent examples being [[Radio Ghaznawiyaan]] and [[Wakht News Agency]]. One document refers to supplying pre-made content to a radio station, describing that content as psychological operations/[[psychological warfare]] (PSYOP) material. ===Insurgent attacks against civilians=== The leaked documents describe many purported incidents of Taliban and other Afghan insurgent forces attacking civilians. Those forces would also, according to leaked reports, post "Night Letters" on civilian buildings such as [[mosques]] foretelling death for the inhabitants. In one leak from April 2007, [[Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs]] [[Karen Hughes]] requests to verify a video of a 12-year-old [[child soldier]] forced to [[summary execution|kill]] a Pakistani hostage. Thomas Joscelyn, a senior fellow at the [[think tank]] [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]], remarked that "the documents demonstrate just how pervasive the Taliban's brutality is in this fight".{{cite news|title=The Taliban's Savagery|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/talibans-savagery|date=3 August 2010|first=Thomas|last=Joscelyn|work=[[The Weekly Standard]]}} ===Child prostitution=== The documents revealed that contractors for the U.S. Department of Defense had hired local male child prostitutes.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/08/wikileaks-reveals-that-mi_n_793816.html "WikiLeaks Reveals That Military Contractors Have Not Lost Their Taste For Child Prostitutes"], Jason Linkins. Huffington Post. 12 December 2010. Accessed 1 March 2011 ==Commentary== ===Significance of the disclosure=== ====WikiLeaks==== Julian Assange said "it is the most comprehensive history of a war ever to be published, during the course of the war". He compared the release of the war logs with the release of the [[Pentagon Papers]] in the 1970s.{{cite news |title=Afghan leak: Wikileaks Julian Assange tells all |newspaper=[[Channel 4]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/politics/international_politics/afghan+leak+wikileaks+julian+assange+tells+all/3723392 |accessdate=27 July 2010}}{{cite news |first1=Anna |last1=Doble |first2=Ed |last2=Fraser |title=Secret files reveal 'unseen Afghan war' |publisher=[[Channel 4]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/politics/international_politics/secret+files+wikileaks+exposes+aposunseen+afghan+warapos/3723387 |accessdate=26 July 2010}} In an interview with ''Der Spiegel'', Assange said that he believed the release would "change public opinion", and said that "we understand why it is important to protect certain U.S. and ISAF sources". He added that "the most dangerous men are those who are in charge of war. And they need to be stopped."{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks Founder Julian Assange on the 'War Logs': 'I Enjoy Crushing Bastards' |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,708518,00.html |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727234634/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C708518%2C00.html# |archivedate=2010-07-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Assange also claimed that the files "suggest thousands of [[war crime]]s".{{cite news|title=Files 'suggest thousands of war crimes,' says Wikileaks founder Julian Assange |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/files-suggest-thousands-of-war-crimes-says-wikileaks-founder-julian-assange-14889654.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20100728010037/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/files-suggest-thousands-of-war-crimes-says-wikileaks-founder-julian-assange-14889654.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 July 2010 |newspaper=[[The Belfast Telegraph]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010}} ====News organisations given advanced access to the documents==== =====''The New York Times''===== ''The New York Times'' described the war logs as "a six-year archive of classified military documents [that] offers an unvarnished and grim picture of the Afghan war". On the decision to publish, they stated: {{blockquote|Deciding whether to publish secret information is always difficult, and after weighing the risks and public interest, we sometimes chose not to publish. But there are times when the information is of significant public interest, and this is one of those times. The documents illuminate the extraordinary difficulty of what the United States and its allies have undertaken in a way that other accounts have not. Most of the incident reports are marked "secret", a relatively low level of classification. The Times has taken care not to publish information that would harm national security interests. The Times and the other news organizations agreed at the outset that we would not disclose – either in our articles or any of our online supplementary material – anything that was likely to put lives at risk or jeopardize military or antiterrorist operations. We have, for example, withheld any names of operatives in the field and informants cited in the reports.}} =====''The Guardian''===== ''The Guardian'' called the material "one of the biggest leaks in U.S. military history...a devastating portrait of the failing [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]], revealing how coalition forces have killed hundreds of civilians in unreported incidents, Taliban attacks have soared and [[NATO]] commanders fear neighbouring Pakistan and Iran are fuelling the insurgency". ''The Guardian'' also reported that [[Daniel Ellsberg]] has described the disclosure as on the scale of his leaking of the [[Pentagon Papers]] in 1971 revealing how the U.S. public was misled about the [[Vietnam War]].{{cite news | first=Richard | last=Norton-Taylor | title=Daniel Ellsberg describes Afghan war logs as on a par with 'Pentagon Papers' | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | date=27 July 2010 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/27/daniel-ellsberg-war-logs-pentagon-papers | accessdate=27 July 2010 | location=London}} =====''Der Spiegel''===== ''Der Spiegel'' wrote that "the editors in chief of ''Spiegel'', ''The New York Times'' and the ''Guardian'' were 'unanimous in their belief that there is a justified public interest in the material{{' "}}. ====Other views==== =====United States military===== U.S. Army officials condemned the public dissemination of military secrets and the White House urged the website WikiLeaks to not publish any more classified documents related to the Afghan war.{{cite web|author=Michael Bowman |url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/Mullen-Leak-of-Afghanistan-Documents-May-Cost-Lives-99720029.html |title=US Military Officials Condemn Leaks of Afghan War Documents |publisher=.voanews.com |date=2010-07-31 |accessdate=2013-07-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/US-Army-Private-in-Wikileaks-Case-Transferred-to-Military-Jail-in-US-99625149.html |title=White House Urges WikiLeaks to Not Publish More Secrets |publisher=.voanews.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}} U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates said that it is up to the Justice Department to determine if there would be criminal charges in the release of classified military documents by WikiLeaks, but the website was "morally guilty for putting lives at risk".{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/POLITICS/08/01/gates.wikileaks/?hpt=T2#fbid=Uplw7ezfGkE |publisher=CNN |title=Gates: Posting classified war documents was morally wrong |date=1 August 2010}} On 6 August 2010, U.S. military authorities urged Wikileaks to return the already published 70,000 documents, and the other 15,000 records the website was expected to post soon as well, which contained sensitive details of Afghans who had assisted ISAF forces. Pentagon spokesman [[Geoff S. Morrell|Geoff Morrell]] said "If doing the right thing is not good enough for them, then we will figure out what alternatives we have to compel them to do the right thing."{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/05/AR2010080504535.html |work=The Washington Post |first=Craig |last=Whitlock |title=Pentagon demands that WikiLeaks give back leaked reports and not post others |date=6 August 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/06/wikileaks-pressure-pentagon-military-files |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=David |last=Batty |title=Pentagon increases pressure on WikiLeaks to return military files |date=6 August 2010}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/7930912/Pentagon-demands-return-of-leaked-documents.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Robert |last=Winnett |title=Pentagon demands return of leaked documents |date=6 August 2010}}{{cite web|author=Taylor Barnes |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2010/0806/Pentagon-threatens-to-compel-WikiLeaks-to-hand-over-Afghan-war-data |title=Pentagon threatens to 'compel' WikiLeaks to hand over Afghan war data |publisher=Csmonitor.com |date=2010-08-06 |accessdate=2013-07-02}} On 7 August 2010, spokesman Daniel Schmitt said that WikiLeaks would continue to publish secret files from governments around the world despite the U.S. demands to cancel plans for further release, claiming that this directly contributed to the public's understanding of the conflict and rejecting allegations that the publication was a threat to America's national security or put lives at risk.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/07/AR2010080701119.html |work=The Washington Post |title=Wikileaks continues to publish secret files}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} =====Afghan authorities===== According to a statement by [[Rangin Dadfar Spanta]], security advisor to the Afghan government and a former Minister of Foreign Affairs, the allies of Afghanistan had failed to pay necessary attention to prevent the support for international terrorism and to eliminate its hideouts and centres that can create a major threat to security and stability in the region. "The content of these documents reveal that Afghanistan has been righteous in its stance about the rise of terrorism and political and military discrepancies in counter-terrorism struggle".{{cite web |url=http://www.tolonews.com/en/afghanistan/155-afghan-allies-have-not-paid-attention-to-the-region-spanta |title=Afghan Allies Have not Paid Attention to the Region: Spanta |publisher=Tolonews.com |date=2010-07-27 |accessdate=2013-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604195431/http://www.tolonews.com/en/afghanistan/155-afghan-allies-have-not-paid-attention-to-the-region-spanta |archivedate=4 June 2013 |df= }} =====Council on Foreign Relations===== Daniel Markey, a senior fellow with the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] and former South Asia analyst for the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]], said,
Whether WikiLeaks uncovered anything new isn't actually important – it's on the front page of every newspaper in the country; the media is now focused on Afghanistan, and that makes it a big deal. [...] The public is now more skeptical about the administration's strategy in Afghanistan than they were last week, and that makes it real.{{cite news |first1=Glenn |last1=Thrush |first2=Josh |last2=Gerstein |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0710/40251.html |title=Leaks loom over W.H. war strategy |newspaper=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727234623/http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0710/40251.html|archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=no}}
=====''Los Angeles Times''===== An editorial in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' stated that comparisons to the Pentagon Papers was an exaggeration as the documents lacked the policy implications of the papers, but that "no democracy can or should fight a war without the consent of its people, and that consent is only meaningful if it is predicated on real information".{{cite news|title=WikiLeaks wasn't wrong |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/editorials/la-ed-wikileaks-20100727,0,4123134.story |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728001408/http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/editorials/la-ed-wikileaks-20100727%2C0%2C4123134.story |archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} The ''Los Angeles Times'' did seem to indicate the documents have parallels with the Pentagon Papers in being published during a subsequent administration "the documents offer insight primarily into the war-fighting of the recently departed George W. Bush administration; the Pentagon Papers ended with the Johnson administration and were not published until Richard Nixon was president." =====''The Washington Post''===== An editorial in ''[[The Washington Post]] ''stated "they hardly provide a secret history of the war or disclose previously unknown malfeasance" and that "tends to fill out and confirm the narrative of Afghanistan between 2004 and 2009 that most Americans are already familiar with".{{cite news |title=Wikileaks' release of classified field reports on Afghan war reveals not much |date=27 July 2010 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/07/26/AR2010072604626.html |accessdate=1 August 2010}} ''The Post'' commented that it hardly merited the media hype and was not comparable to the Pentagon Papers or the [[Stasi#The MfS files after the end of the SED regime|MfS files]]. The editorial argued that WikiLeaks' founder revealed his organization's antiwar agenda by making the claim it contained evidence for prosecuting [[war crime]]s. =====''Foreign Policy''===== Blake Hounshell wrote in his blog on ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' that, after reading "selected documents", he believed that there is less new information in the documents than ''The New York Times'', ''The Guardian'', and ''Der Spiegel'' were reporting.{{cite web |first=Blake |last=Hounshell |title=The logs of war: Do the Wikileaks documents really tell us anything new? |date=25 July 2010 |url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2010/07/25/the_logs_of_war |work=[[Foreign Policy]] |accessdate=26 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729130800/http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2010/07/25/the_logs_of_war|archivedate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Hounshell indicated how careful both ''The Guardian'' and ''The New York Times'' were to note "the raw reports in the Wikileaks archive often seem poorly sourced and present implausible information". Commenting on the significance of the documents: {{blockquote|I'd say that so far the documents confirm what we already know about the war: It's going badly; Pakistan is not the world's greatest ally and is probably playing a double game; coalition forces have been responsible for far too many civilian casualties; and the United States doesn't have very reliable intelligence in Afghanistan.}} ===Legality of the disclosure=== Ann Woolner wrote in an editorial in ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' that WikiLeaks' publication of the documents is legally allowed in the United States because the group did not solicit the documents.{{cite news |first1=Ann |last1=Woolner |title=WikiLeaks Secret Records Dump Stays in Legal Clear |newspaper=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=27 July 2010 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-28/wikileaks-secret-records-dump-stays-in-legal-clear-ann-woolner.html |accessdate=27 July 2010}} Asking someone to leak secret information, "with intent or reason to believe that the information to be obtained is to be used to the injury of the United States", would violate the United States' [[Espionage Act of 1917]] In violation of the post-World War I accord.{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Duffy |url=http://www.firstworldwar.com/source/espionageact.htm |title=Primary Documents – U.S. Espionage Act, 15 June 1917 |publisher=firstworldwar.com |date=22 August 2009 |accessdate=28 July 2010}}{{cite web|last=Synovitz |first=Ron |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Wikileaks_Afghan_War_Reports_Stir_Debates_On_Journalism_Law/2111395.html |title=WikiLeaks' Afghan War Reports Stir Debates On Journalism, Law |publisher=Rferl.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-02}} ==Reactions== {{flag|EU}} An official from the [[European Union]] has told [[The Associated Press]] "that the organization 'wants to stay as far from this as possible.{{' }} {{flag|Afghanistan}} – While the [[Afghan government]] has stated that the majority of the leaked documents did not comprise new information, it has expressed concern over both Pakistan's connection with the Taliban and the United States' involvement in their funding.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010|reason=precise citation with attributed quotes needed here. CNN cite does quote Herawi's call for US to do something about ISI but nothing about funding. Also needs rewrite because "their" is ambiguous}} [[Siamak Herawi]], deputy spokesman for the office of the President,{{cite web |url=http://www.president.gov.af/sroot_eng.aspx?id=90 |title=President Office |CONTACT THE SPOKESPERSON |publisher=President.gov.af |date=10 June 2009 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730141620/http://www.president.gov.af/sroot_eng.aspx?id=90 |archivedate=2010-07-30 |deadurl=yes |df= }} stated: "There should be serious action taken against the [[Inter-Services Intelligence]], who has a direct connection with the [[terrorist]]s. These reports show that the United States was already aware of the ISI connection with the [[al Qaeda]] terrorist network. The United States is overdue on the ISI issue, and now the United States, should answer."{{cite news |title=World powers react to WikiLeaks' documents |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/07/26/afghanistan.wikileaks.reaction/#fbid=DgdbaWvUDTp |accessdate=27 July 2010}} {{flagu|Australia}} – [[Australian Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]] has stated that the [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]] will investigate the content of the leaks to examine what the implications are for Australia, which had 1,500 troops deployed in Afghanistan.{{cite news |first=Kim |last=Landers |title=Defence taskforce to examine leaked war files |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/07/27/2965693.htm |date=27 July 2010 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=27 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729130451/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/07/27/2965693.htm|archivedate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} This investigation concluded in October 2010 and found that the leaked documents "had not had a direct significant adverse impact on Australia's national interests".{{cite web|title=Afghan WikiLeaks no threat |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/defencenews/stories/2010/Oct/1026b.htm|publisher=Australian Department of Defence|accessdate=29 October 2010|date=26 October 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029163319/http://www.defence.gov.au/defencenews/stories/2010/Oct/1026b.htm|archivedate=29 October 2010 |deadurl=no}} {{flagu|Canada}} – The Canadian [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Lawrence Cannon]] said the leak could endanger Canadian troops.{{cite news |title=Canada says leaked Afghan papers could hurt troops |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE66P4G620100726 |date=26 July 2010 |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |accessdate=27 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729165650/http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE66P4G620100726|archivedate=29 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Canada also disputed one of the records, saying it inaccurately described an incident as friendly fire.{{cite news |title=DND, families of dead soldiers say leaked friendly-fire report is wrong |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/afghanmission/article/840583--dnd-families-of-dead-soldiers-say-leaked-friendly-fire-report-is-wrong |date=27 July 2010 |newspaper=[[Toronto Star]] |agency=[[The Canadian Press]] |accessdate=27 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728230618/http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/afghanmission/article/840583--dnd-families-of-dead-soldiers-say-leaked-friendly-fire-report-is-wrong|archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Another document suggests that a Canadian was among the casualties in a helicopter that was destroyed by heat-seeking missiles. The document indicates that the United States wanted Canada to put pressure on [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[South Africa]], where the United States believed Taliban fundraising was taking place. The documents claim that American diplomats spoke with two senior Canadian Foreign Affairs officials in their appeal for the Canadian government to join the U.S. government in issuing a joint diplomatic rebuke to Saudi Arabia and South Africa. The documents also allege that Canada was asked to rebuke the [[United Arab Emirates]] independently over alleged militant fundraising.{{cite news |title=S. Africa suspected of Taliban fundraising: memo |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/07/26/cannon-afghanistan-leaked-documents-iran.html |accessdate=27 July 2010}} One document suggests that a Canadian [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 Hercules]] was hit with an [[anti-aircraft weapon]] fired by the Taliban during takeoff. The document states that the C-130's landing gear and some of its [[fuselage]] was destroyed by a 14.5 mm round as the aircraft departed from the western province of [[Farah Province|Farah]], with the report stating, "It is unusual that insurgents would engage aircraft in such close proximity to an airfield with a weapon of this caliber." The documents also say that a number of Canadian unmanned drones have crashed and that in one instance, locals removed a vehicle's technology before soldiers could recover it.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/07/27/wikileak-document-hercules.html |publisher=[[CBC News]] |title=Canadian aircraft hit by Taliban: leaked report |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=27 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728230046/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2010/07/27/wikileak-document-hercules.html|archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Cannon refused to comment on the documents, saying that they had "nothing to do with Canada" and denied the Canadian government was misleading its citizens on the war in Afghanistan. [[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democratic Party]] leader [[Jack Layton]] said that the documents "undermines the confidence" Canadian citizens have in their government and called on politicians to "get to the bottom of" the situation regarding the friendly fire report. {{flagu|Germany}} – The German government has stated that the documents could place its 4,600 troops in danger, and condemns their release.{{cite news |title=US fed up with Germany's war effort, files show |newspaper=[[The Local]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=http://www.thelocal.de/politics/20100726-28751.html |accessdate=27 July 2010}} During a meeting in [[Brussels]], [[Guido Westerwelle]], the German [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Germany)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]], has suggested that the entirety should be "carefully examined, to see what possible new revelations there might be".{{cite news |title=Afghanistan war logs: as it happened |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=26 July 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2010/jul/26/afghanistan-war-logs-wikileaks |accessdate=27 July 2010 |location=London |first1=Richard |last1=Adams |first2=Haroon |last2=Siddique |first3=Matthew |last3=Weaver}} In general, the government "has shown little alarm over the release of the documents", with a spokesman from the [[Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)|Federal Ministry of Defence]] stating that there was "nothing newsworthy"; however, opposition party [[Alliance '90/The Greens|The Greens]] welcomed the release of the files, with [[Claudia Roth]] stating that "[the] WikiLeaks documents prove just how dramatic the situation in Afghanistan is", and "show the lengths the allies are prepared to go to in their fight for more stability". The Greens also showed distrust in the federal government over the lack of disclosure of U.S. special forces activities in German-controlled areas. [[Omid Nouripour]], the security spokesman for the party, said, "On our reading of the U.S. documents, it is disturbing how little the federal government has informed the parliament about the activities of American special forces in German areas. We demand an immediate explanation from the federal government as to what they know about the missions. We will push with all force for answers." {{flagu|India}} – The [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Ministry of External Affairs]] said:{{cite web |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/wikileaks-india-says-pak-must-stop-sponsorship-of-terrorism-40215?cp |title=WikiLeaks: India says Pak must stop 'sponsorship of terrorism' |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=29 July 2010 |publisher=[[NDTV]]}} {{quotation|We have seen media reports about classified information, supposedly from US government sources, put out in public domain, on support to terrorism by [[Inter-Services Intelligence|ISI]] – Pakistan's military intelligence agency. Sponsorship of terrorism, as an instrument of policy, is wholly condemnable and must cease forthwith. The utilisation of territory under Pakistan's control to provide sanctuaries for recruiting and sustaining terrorist groups, and to direct terrorist activity against neighbors, must stop if our region is to attain its full potential for peaceful development.}} {{flagu|Pakistan}} – Pakistani President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] announced via spokesman [[Farhatullah Babar]] that allegations about [[Inter-Services Intelligence|ISI]]'s involvement "have been regurgitated in the past. Also, these represent low-level intelligence reports and do not represent a convincing smoking gun. I do not see any convincing evidence." The spokesman continued rhetorically, asking if "those who are alleging that Pakistan is playing a double game are also asserting that President Zardari is presiding over an apparatus that is coordinating attacks on the general headquarters, [[mosque]]s, shrines, schools and killing Pakistani citizens?"{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0710/40251_Page2.html#ixzz0uxlLC9B8 |title=Leaks loom over W.H. war strategy |newspaper=[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727234917/http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0710/40251_Page2.html|archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Pakistan's ambassador to the United States [[Husain Haqqani]] on Sunday denounced the leak of secret files calling them as "irresponsible", saying it consisted of "unprocessed" reports from the field. "The documents circulated by WikiLeaks do not reflect the current onground realities", he said in a statement.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/12-afghan+war+leak+irresponsible+inaccurate+haqqani--bi-04 |title=Afghan war leak 'irresponsible': Haqqani |newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728115613/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/12-afghan%2Bwar%2Bleak%2Birresponsible%2Binaccurate%2Bhaqqani--bi-04 |archivedate=28 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} A senior ISI official denied the allegations, saying they were from raw intelligence reports that had not been verified and were meant to impugn the reputation of the spy agency. He spoke on condition of anonymity in line with the agency's policy. Former ISI Chief [[Hamid Gul]], who headed the agency in the late 1980s when Pakistan and the United States were supporting militants in their fight against the [[Soviet Union|Soviets]] in Afghanistan, denied the allegations that he was working with the Taliban, saying "these leaked documents against me are fiction and nothing else".{{cite news |url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/03-isi-denounces-us-intelligence-reports-ss-10 |title=ISI denounces US intelligence reports |newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727213317/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/03-isi-denounces-us-intelligence-reports-ss-10|archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} Politicians and defense analysts critically commented on leaks and the western media in using the ISI card while not highlighting most of the civilian casualties resulting from bombing of [[NATO]] forces like how U.S. special forces dropped six 2,000 lb bombs on a compound where they believed a "high-value individual" was hiding, after "ensuring there were no innocent Afghans in the surrounding area". In fact, up to 300 civilians had died in those attacks. {{flagu|United Kingdom}} – On July 28, Britain announced that it would launch two new inquiries into the country's role in the war. A committee member said the launching of the inquiries had nothing to do with the Wikileaks documents.{{cite web |title=Britain to launch Afghan war inquiry |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=136666§ionid=351021806 |publisher=[[Press TV]] |date=29 July 2010 |accessdate=30 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100730224508/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=136666§ionid=351021806|archivedate=30 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} {{flagu|United States}} – [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] [[James L. Jones]] and Pakistan's ambassador to the United States, [[Husain Haqqani]], both condemned [[WikiLeaks]] for an "irresponsible" disclosure.{{cite news |first=Roger |last=Runningen |title=U.S. Condemns Release of Documents on Afghan War |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=25 July 2010 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-25/u-s-denounces-publication-of-classified-documents-on-war-in-afghanistan.html |accessdate=26 July 2010}} White House National Security Advisor James Jones issued a statement to reporters shortly before the documents were posted online, saying the leaks were "irresponsible" but would not impact U.S. strategy in Afghanistan and Pakistan. "The United States strongly condemns the disclosure of classified information by individuals and organizations which could put the lives of Americans and our partners at risk, and threaten our national security", he said in his statement, "These irresponsible leaks will not impact our ongoing commitment to deepen our partnerships with Afghanistan and Pakistan; to defeat our common enemies; and to support the aspirations of the Afghan and Pakistani people."{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/world/12-us+condemns+leak+alleging+pakistan+spy-insurgent+links--bi-03 |title=US condemns leak alleging Pakistan spy-insurgent links |newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |date=26 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727193840/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/world/12-us%2Bcondemns%2Bleak%2Balleging%2Bpakistan%2Bspy-insurgent%2Blinks--bi-03 |archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} * Deputy National Security Advisor for Strategic Communications [[Ben Rhodes (White House staffer)|Ben Rhodes]] stated that "[since] taking office, President Obama has been very clear and candid with the American people about the challenges that we face in Afghanistan and Pakistan. [...] It is important to note that the time period reflected in the documents is January 2004 to December 2009. The war in Afghanistan was under-resourced for many years. [...] On Dec. 1, 2009, President Obama announced a new strategy and new resources for Afghanistan and Pakistan precisely because of the grave situation there", and that they "strongly condemn the disclosure of classified information by individuals and organizations that put the lives of the U.S. and partner service members at risk and threatens our national security."[http://www.centcom.mil/en/news/statement-of-national-security-advisor-gen-james-jones-on-wikileaks "Statement of National Security Advisor Gen. James Jones on Wikileaks"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728135527/http://www.centcom.mil/en/news/statement-of-national-security-advisor-gen-james-jones-on-wikileaks |date=July 28, 2010 }} * Representative [[Dennis Kucinich]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]) of [[Ohio]] said "These documents provide a fuller picture of what we have long known about Afghanistan: The war is going badly. We have to show the ability to respond to what's right in front of our face: This war is no longer justifiable under any circumstances".{{cite news |first=Gail |last=Russell Chaddock |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2010/0727/Congress-s-response-to-WikiLeaks-shoot-the-messenger |title=Congress's response to WikiLeaks: shoot the messenger |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=27 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727234406/http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2010/0727/Congress-s-response-to-WikiLeaks-shoot-the-messenger|archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] chairman Senator [[John Kerry]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]]) of [[Massachusetts]] said "However illegally these documents came to light, they raise serious questions about the reality of America's policy toward Pakistan and Afghanistan. Those policies are at a critical stage and these documents may very well underscore the stakes and make the calibrations needed to get the policy right more urgent." In a later release he was quoted as saying "All of us [are] concerned that after nine years of war ... the Taliban appear to be as strong as they have been".{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gf-LrC8N0v5YdSCKyj1VpyZxImOA |title=Top US senator: Don't 'overhype' Afghan war leak |publisher=[[Google]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727234333/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gf-LrC8N0v5YdSCKyj1VpyZxImOA|archivedate=27 July 2010 |deadurl=no}} [[Taliban]] – spokesperson, [[Zabihullah Mujahid]], has stated they are inspecting the leaked documents which contain the names, tribes, and family information of Afghan informants who were helping the United States. "We knew about the spies and people who collaborate with U.S. forces", he said. "We will investigate through our own secret service whether the people mentioned are really spies working for the United States.
