'''''Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)''''', commonly known simply as '''''Birdman''''', is a 2014 American [[black comedy]] film directed by [[Alejandro González Iñárritu|Alejandro G. Iñárritu]]. It was written by Iñárritu, [[Nicolás Giacobone]], [[Alexander Dinelaris Jr.]], and [[Armando Bó (screenwriter)|Armando Bo]]. The film stars [[Michael Keaton]] with a supporting cast of [[Zach Galifianakis]], [[Edward Norton]], [[Andrea Riseborough]], [[Amy Ryan]], [[Emma Stone]], and [[Naomi Watts]]. The story follows Riggan Thomson (Keaton), a faded Hollywood actor best known for playing the superhero "Birdman", as he struggles to mount a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] adaptation of a short story by [[Raymond Carver]].
The film covers the period of previews leading to the play's opening, and with a brief exception appears as if filmed in a [[One shot (film)|single shot]], an idea Iñárritu had from the film's conception. [[Emmanuel Lubezki]], who won the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for his cinematography in ''Birdman'', believed that the recording time necessary for the [[long take]] approach taken in ''Birdman'' could not have been made with older technology. The film was shot in [[New York City]] during the spring of 2013 with a budget of $16.5 million jointly financed by [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]], [[Regency Enterprises|New Regency Pictures]] and [[Worldview Entertainment]]. It premiered the following year in August where it opened the [[71st Venice International Film Festival]].
''Birdman'' had a limited theatrical release in the United States on October 17, 2014, followed by a wide release on November 14, grossing more than $103 million worldwide. The film won the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]], along with [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]], [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]], and [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography]] from a total of nine nominations, tying it with ''[[The Grand Budapest Hotel]]'' for the most nominated and awarded film at the Academy's [[87th Academy Awards|87th annual awards ceremony]] with four wins per film. It also won Outstanding Cast in a Motion Picture at the [[21st Screen Actors Guild Awards]], as well as [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor in a Musical or Comedy]] for Keaton and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]] at the [[72nd Golden Globe Awards]].
==Plot== {{Anchor|Synopsis|Plot}}Riggan Thomson is a faded American actor who is famous for playing the [[superhero]] Birdman in a film trilogy 20 years ago. He is tormented by the mocking and critical internal voice of Birdman and frequently visualises himself performing feats of [[levitation (paranormal)|levitation]] and [[Psychokinesis|telekinesis]]. Riggan is trying to gain recognition as a serious actor for writing, directing, and starring in a Broadway adaptation of [[Raymond Carver]]'s short story "[[What We Talk About When We Talk About Love#"What We Talk About When We Talk About Love"|What We Talk About When We Talk About Love]]."
Jake, Riggan's best friend and lawyer, is producing the play which co-stars Riggan's girlfriend Laura and Broadway débutante Lesley. Riggan's daughter Sam, a recovering drug addict whom he is trying to reconnect with, is working as his assistant. The day before the first preview, a light fixture falls onto Riggan's hapless co-star Ralph, which Riggan tells Jake he caused. At Lesley's suggestion, Riggan replaces Ralph with her boyfriend, the brilliant but volatile [[method acting|method actor]] Mike Shiner. The first previews are disastrous: Mike breaks character over the replacement of his gin with water, attempts to have real sex with Lesley during a sex scene and claims that the prop gun does not look real which is hindering his performance. Riggan clashes continually with Mike and is incensed at influential theater critic Tabitha Dickinson's praise for Mike's performance, but Jake persuades him to continue with the play. Riggan catches Sam using marijuana and berates her; she tells him he is expendable and that his play is a vanity project.
During the final preview, Riggan accidentally locks himself outside with his robe stuck in the fire escape door. He is forced to walk through [[Times Square]] in his underwear and enter through the audience to do the final scene. A concerned Sam is waiting in his dressing room after the show. She thinks the performance was very weird but sort of cool. She shows him that the Times Square footage is going [[Viral video|viral]] and explains how this actually helps him.
Riggan goes to a bar for a drink and approaches Tabitha, accusing her of not understanding theater and just crudely labeling things. She tells him that she hates ignorant Hollywood celebrities who pretend to be serious actors and promises to "kill" his play with a deprecating review without even having seen it. On the way back, Riggan buys a pint of whiskey, drinks it and passes out on a stoop. The next day, walking to the theater with a severe hangover, he has a conversation with the now visible Birdman, who tries to convince him to quit the play and make a fourth Birdman film. Riggan visualises himself flying through the streets of Manhattan before arriving at the theater.
On the opening night the play is going very well. In his dressing room, a strangely calm Riggan confesses to his ex-wife Sylvia that several years ago he attempted to drown himself in the ocean after she caught him having an affair. He also tells her about his inner Birdman voice, which she ignores. After Sylvia wishes him luck and leaves the room, Riggan picks up a real gun, rather than a prop, for the final scene in which his character commits suicide. At the climax, Riggan shoots himself in the head on-stage. The play receives a [[standing ovation]] as Tabitha rushes out to file copy.
The next day, Riggan wakes up in a hospital with his face covered in a mask of bandages where his nose has been surgically reconstructed after he blew it off during the botched suicide. Sylvia is worried about him but Jake cannot contain his excitement that the play will run forever after Tabitha's rave-review which called the suicide attempt "super-realism" and just what American theater needed. Sam visits with flowers, which he cannot smell, and takes a picture of him to scare the skyrocketing number of followers on the [[Twitter]] account she has created for him. While she steps outside to find a vase, Riggan goes into the bathroom, removes the bandages revealing his swollen new nose, and obscenely says goodbye to Birdman, whom he sees sitting on the toilet. Fascinated by some birds flying outside his room, he opens the window and climbs out onto the ledge. When Sam returns, Riggan is nowhere to be seen. She frantically scans the ground below the open window before slowly looking up into the sky, smiling, and laughing.

==Production==
===Development=== ''Birdman'' director [[Alejandro González Iñárritu|Alejandro G. Iñárritu]] originally conceived the film as a comedy filmed in a [[long take|single shot]] set in a theatre. The original choice behind the film's genre, which was subsequently re-adapted to concentrate on Riggan's final emotional tail spin, came from the director wanting to see a change in his approach. All his previous films were dramas, and after directing ''[[Biutiful]]'', he did not want to approach his new film in the same tragic manner again.<ref name="genocide">{{cite web|title=Alejandro G. Iñárritu And 'Birdman' Scribes On Hollywood's Superhero Fixation: 'Poison, Cultural Genocide' – Q&A |last=Fleming Jr |first=Mike |date=October 15, 2014 |website=Deadline Hollywood |url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/birdman-director-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-writers-interview-852206/ |accessdate=February 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225110900/http://deadline.com/2014/10/birdman-director-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-writers-interview-852206/ |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The decision to make the film appear as a single shot came from his realization that "we live our lives with no editing." By presenting the film as a continuous shot he could "submerge the protagonist in an 'inescapable reality' and take the audience with him".<ref name="varScott">{{cite web|title=Interview: 'Birdman' Director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu on His First Comedy |last=Foundas |first=Scott |date=August 27, 2014 |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-birdman-interview-1201292156/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=February 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225110002/http://variety.com/2014/film/news/alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-birdman-interview-1201292156/ |archivedate=February 25, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Iñárritu shared his idea with the Argentine screenwriters/cousins [[Nicolás Giacobone]] and [[Armando Bó (screenwriter)|Armando Bo]], as well as playwright [[Alexander Dinelaris Jr.]], who had all worked with him on his previous film.<ref name="CS">{{cite web|title=Birdman: "Completely one shot? Don't even try it" |last=McKittrick |first=Christopher |date=November 26, 2014 |publisher=Creative Screenwriting Magazine |url=http://creativescreenwriting.com/birdman-completely-one-shot-dont-even-try-it/|accessdate=February 14, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209063001/http://creativescreenwriting.com/birdman-completely-one-shot-dont-even-try-it/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>{{efn|Dinelaris contributed some of the first drafts,<ref name=bio>{{cite web|title=The Bookish World of 'Birdman:' A Q&A with Writer Alex Dinelaris |last=Sauer |first=Patrick |date=October 23, 2014 |publisher=Biographile |url=http://www.biographile.com/qa-screenwriter-alex-dinelaris-reveals-process-behind-birdman-script/37122/ |accessdate=February 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212160447/http://www.biographile.com/qa-screenwriter-alex-dinelaris-reveals-process-behind-birdman-script/37122/ |archivedate=February 12, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Bo and Giacobone co-wrote the film.}} Their first reaction was to tell him the continuous-shot idea could not work.<ref name="genocide" /> According to Dinelaris and Giacobone, "huge" and "important" people told him to not even try the project for the same reason.<ref name="CS" /> Iñárritu himself described the technique as "almost suicidal", worrying that it would be distracting instead of immersive.<ref name="hammond">{{cite web|title=Daring Do |last=Hammond |first=Pete |url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-birdman-director-interview-michael-keaton-1201341925/ |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=January 6, 2015 |accessdate=February 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209062947/http://deadline.com/2015/01/alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-birdman-director-interview-michael-keaton-1201341925/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Dinelaris later said that had they truly paused and considered the idea, they might have talked Iñárritu out of it.<ref name="genocide" />
The personal and vocational experiences of the four co-writers were central to writing the script. Dinelaris' exposure to Broadway shaped the depictions of rehearsals and events backstage, though he admitted exaggerating these. He also felt his background writing long scenes of dialogue helped since scenes in the film "were really more like play scenes".<ref name="CS" /> Iñárritu's own experiences influenced many of ''Birdman''{{'}}s themes. "What this film talks about, I have been through," Iñárritu recalled. "I have seen and experienced all of it; it's what I have been living through the last years of my life."<ref name="genocide" /> Dinelaris described this aspect as "a laughing look at oneself", but said it had to be done in a comedic way otherwise "it would have been the most unbelievably self-absorbed look at the subject".<ref name="genocide" /> Themes from [[Raymond Carver]]'s short story "[[What We Talk About When We Talk About Love]]", which Riggan adapts for stage in the story, also influenced the script. Iñárritu wanted to find the connection between the themes in Riggan's story and those of Carver's.<ref name="CS" /> Because of this, it was important to the director that Carver's story be the subject of the play depicted within the film. Therefore, Iñárritu stated that his desire to use Carver's work was "terrifying" because the rights to using the Carver material were still subject to the possibility of being rejected during development of the film, but no issues arose. Carver's widow, writer [[Tess Gallagher]], loved the script and permitted the adaptation, saying that Carver would be laughing about the film.<ref name="genocide" />
While some aspects of the film{{snd}} the first frame with Riggan, for instance{{snd}} went unchanged from ''Birdman's'' conception to release,<ref name="genocide" /> others went through several iterations. One of these was the sequence in which alter ego Birdman takes complete control over Riggan's thoughts. The writers knew it would occur at Riggan's lowest point, so at one stage planned for it to happen after Riggan hears the initial negative press coverage and destroys his dressing room. In another discarded version, Riggan tries to drown himself in [[Central Park]] and flies out to save himself.<ref name="CS" />
The film's ending also changed, the final version being written halfway through filming.<ref name="Taylor 2">{{cite web|title=Interview: Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu Talks 'Birdman,' The Film's "Bad" Original Ending, Critics, 'True Detective' & More |last=Taylor |first=Drew |date=January 8, 2015 |publisher=Indiewire.com |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/interview-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-talks-birdman-the-films-bad-original-ending-critics-true-detective-more-20150108?page=2 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212010101/http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/interview%2Dalejandro%2Dgonzalez%2Dinarritu%2Dtalks%2Dbirdman%2Dthe%2Dfilms%2Dbad%2Doriginal%2Dending%2Dcritics%2Dtrue%2Ddetective%2Dmore%2D20150108?page%3D2|accessdate=February 12, 2015 |archivedate=February 12, 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> The original intended to depict [[Johnny Depp]] in Riggan's dressing room with a ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean]]'' poster in the back. Iñárritu grew to strongly dislike this ending, calling it "so embarrassing", and rewrote it with Dinelaris and Giacobone after a new ending came to him in a dream.<ref name="Taylor 2"/><ref name="intvmag_inarritu" /> Iñárritu was reluctant to describe the original ending but it was leaked by Dinelaris. He said the original ending was set in the theatre instead of the hospital, and involved Depp putting on Riggan Thomson's wig, and in [[Jack Sparrow|Jack Sparrow's]] voice "...the poster asks Depp, 'What the fuck are we doing here, mate?' and it was going to be the satire of the endless loop of that."<ref name="taylor2">{{cite web|title=Interview: Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu Talks 'Birdman,' The Film's "Bad" Original Ending, Critics, 'True Detective' & More |last=Taylor |first=Drew |date=January 8, 2015 |publisher=Indiewire.com |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/interview-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-talks-birdman-the-films-bad-original-ending-critics-true-detective-more-20150108?page=2 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212010101/http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/interview%2Dalejandro%2Dgonzalez%2Dinarritu%2Dtalks%2Dbirdman%2Dthe%2Dfilms%2Dbad%2Doriginal%2Dending%2Dcritics%2Dtrue%2Ddetective%2Dmore%2D20150108?page%3D2|accessdate=August 20, 2015 |archivedate=February 12, 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> The director and co-authors ruled out the satirical ending, and favored the new, more ambiguous, ending.<ref name="intvmag_inarritu" /><ref name="taylor2"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Here's How Johnny Depp Could Have Appeared in Birdman |last=Miller |first=Julie |date=February 10, 2015 |work=Vanity Fair |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/02/johnny-depp-birdman |accessdate=August 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212160450/http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/02/johnny-depp-birdman |archivedate=February 12, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
The project of co-writing was expedited by the collaboration between the four co-writers on the internet working from different geographical locations. With Iñárritu in [[Los Angeles]], Giacobone and Bo in [[Buenos Aires City|Buenos Aires]], and Dinelaris in New York, the script was mainly written through Skype calls and emails.<ref name="genocide" /> Although this complicated the writing process, Dinelaris said he believed the best ideas in ''Birdman'' came from Skype sessions at two in the morning where he and Giacobone were "cracking each other up". Incorporating the one-shot feature also affected the writing. Bo said "We wrote everything thinking of this one shot, and a lot of decisions that would mostly be taken in the editing room were taken before shooting". The one-shot approach meant the scenes could not be removed or re-ordered in post-production, so the writers needed to be "very, very sure about what was on the page."<ref name="CS" /> As a result, it took about a year and a half to complete the final draft.<ref name="SCU">{{cite web|title=BIRDMAN Writers Thought No One Would 'Get It' |last=Milly |first=Jenna |date=December 5, 2014 |publisher=ScreenwritingU |url=http://www.screenwritingu.com/blog/birdman |accessdate=February 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212153111/http://www.screenwritingu.com/blog/birdman |archivedate=February 12, 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> As [[Alexander Dinelaris|Dinelaris]] summarized: "You have to be an idiot to do it all in one shot. You have to be an idiot to attempt it. It takes a great, great deal of ignorance to not pay attention to the difficulties and to think you're going to do this. ''Birdman'' looks like a good idea now, but [at the time of production] we did not know how we would land."<ref name=CS />
===Casting=== [[File:Michael Keaton by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Michael Keaton]] was Iñárritu's first choice to play Riggan Thomson]]
Iñárritu cast several of the leading roles before the film was financed.<ref name="financiers">{{cite web |title=How 'Birdman' Got Made: Fox Searchlight and New Regency Partners Tell All (Keaton, Norton, Stone VIDEOS) |last=Thompson |first=Anne |author-link=Anne Thompson (film critic) |date=October 21, 2014 |publisher=Thompson on Hollywood |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/how-birdman-got-made-fox-searchlight-and-new-regency-partners-tell-all-keaton-norton-stone-videos-20141021 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225134236/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/how-birdman-got-made-fox-searchlight-and-new-regency-partners-tell-all-keaton-norton-stone-videos-20141021 |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Among these was the lead role. Early in script development, Iñárritu did not have Keaton in mind,<ref name="varScott" /> but he had changed his mind by the end: "When I finished the script, I knew that Michael was not the choice or option, he was the guy".<ref name="NYT_Kíton">{{cite news|title=Everyman Returns |last=Ryzik |first=Melena |date=October 8, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/12/movies/in-birdman-michael-keaton-confronts-the-nature-of-fame.html |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215053658/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/12/movies/in-birdman-michael-keaton-confronts-the-nature-of-fame.html |archivedate=February 15, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Iñárritu cast Keaton for his depth in a variety of acting styles: he could handle the demands of the stage, up-close work, and comedy and empathy "with a profound depth to both."<ref>{{cite news|title=A Normal Day in the Unusual Life of Michael Keaton |last=Chiarella |first=Tom |date=January 28, 2014 |work=Esquire |url=http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/interviews/a26339/michael-keaton-interview-0214/ |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WbebfXN7?url=http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/interviews/a26339/michael-keaton-interview-0214/ |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no |df=mdy}}</ref>
Keaton knew about ''Birdman'' before Iñárritu contacted him. He was in the middle of production of another project when he learned that Iñárritu was making another film. Keaton, a fan of his work, flew home to find out more.<ref>{{cite web|title=It Took Michael Keaton About 27 Seconds To Decide To Be In 'Birdman' |last=Acuna |first=Kirsten |date=October 18, 2014 |publisher=Business Insider |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/birdman-michael-keaton-casting-2014-10 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WbgWvaS4?url=http://www.businessinsider.com/birdman-michael-keaton-casting-2014-10 |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no |df=mdy}}</ref> Iñárritu sent him the script and they discussed it over dinner. The first thing Keaton asked the director was whether he was making fun of him (regarding his role in [[Tim Burton]]'s [[Batman in film#Tim Burton/Joel Schumacher|''Batman'' films]]), but after Iñárritu explained the role, its technicalities and the film's production, Keaton agreed to play Riggan.<ref name="varScott" />
Iñárritu called his decision behind casting Galifianakis as Jake "a bet". Galifianakis met the director's criteria of being lovable and funny, but Iñárritu also considered him sensitive, which scored him the role.<ref name="rappler">{{cite web|title=Interview: 'Birdman' director Alejandro Gonzalez Iñarritu |work=Rappler |date=January 17, 2015 |publisher=Rappler.com |url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/movies/81025-birdman-director-alejandro-gonzales-inarritu-interview |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225131953/http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/movies/81025-birdman-director-alejandro-gonzales-inarritu-interview |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Emma Stone already knew she wanted to work with Iñárritu before she was offered the role of Sam. The script that Iñárritu gave her and the rest of the cast came with the photo ''Man on Wire'', which featured [[Philippe Petit]] crossing the Twin Towers on a tightrope. Iñárritu told the cast, "We are doing that".<ref name="intvmag_inarritu">{{cite web|title=Alejandro González Iñárritu |last=Mitchell |first=Elvis |work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] |url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu/ |accessdate=February 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="bold">{{cite web|title=Bold Statement |last=D'Alessandro |first=Alessandro |date=December 22, 2014 |website=Deadline Hollywood |url=http://deadline.com/2014/12/emma-stone-birdman-interview-alejandro-inarritu-1201330997/ |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225134819/http://deadline.com/2014/12/emma-stone-birdman-interview-alejandro-inarritu-1201330997/ |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
Once these actors were committed, Iñárritu sought funding. He first invited [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] to finance the project, but they turned his offer down because they felt his asking budget was too high.<ref name="financiers" /> At one stage Megan Ellison of [[Annapurna Pictures]] wanted to be involved in the project, but decided against it because, unlike her other films, she had not been involved since the beginning.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview: Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu Talks 'Birdman,' The Film's "Bad" Original Ending, Critics, 'True Detective' & More |last=Taylor |first=Drew |date=January 8, 2015 |publisher=IndieWire |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/interview-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-talks-birdman-the-films-bad-original-ending-critics-true-detective-more-20150108 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225134600/http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/interview-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-talks-birdman-the-films-bad-original-ending-critics-true-detective-more-20150108 |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Iñárritu approached Brad Weston, president of [[New Regency]], who accepted the offer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Making of 'Birdman': Alejandro G. Inarritu Recounts Harrowing Experience Behind His First Comedy |last=McClintock |first=Pamela |date=January 8, 2015 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/making-birdman-alejandro-g-inarritu-761407 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211030036/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/making-birdman-alejandro-g-inarritu-761407 |archivedate=February 11, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> When executive Claudia Lewis of Searchlight heard about the deal, she reconsidered and asked to be included in the deal. Searchlight and New Regency had previously worked together to finance ''[[12 Years a Slave (film)|12 Years a Slave]]'', and they decided to join together for ''Birdman'', financing a budget of $16.5 million.<ref name="financiers" />
Weston and Lewis developed a close relationship with Iñárritu, editing the script with him and switching some of the actors. When they joined production, [[Josh Brolin]] was set to play the role of Mike Shiner, but the financiers decided to switch him for Norton because of scheduling conflicts.<ref name="financiers" />
He said Norton's experience as a theatre actor combined with his self-confidence meant that "in a way there was some kind of mental reality to Edward",<ref name="rappler" /> but Norton believes he was the one who convinced Iñárritu to take him on. Norton was a fan of the director's work and impressed with his ability to push outside film-making boundaries.<ref name="ed_and_andrea">{{cite web|title=Edward Norton and Andrea Riseborough Dig Into Actors' Egos and 'Birdman' |last=Thompson |first=Anne |date=October 24, 2014 |publisher=Thompson on Hollywood |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/edward-norton-and-andrea-riseborough-dig-into-actors-egos-and-birdman-20141024 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215081155/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/edward-norton-and-andrea-riseborough-dig-into-actors-egos-and-birdman-20141024 |archivedate=February 15, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Norton heard about Iñárritu's project from a friend. Once he got the script, he read it straight through until 3:00 am. Norton said, "I laughed so hard I woke people up."<ref>{{cite web|title=Michael Keaton and Edward Norton take a trip through the weird world of 'Birdman' |last=Sarkar |first=Samit |date=October 15, 2014 |publisher=Polygon |url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/15/6985135/birdman-panel-nycc-2014-michael-keaton-edward-norton |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225134353/http://www.polygon.com/2014/10/15/6985135/birdman-panel-nycc-2014-michael-keaton-edward-norton |archivedate=February 25, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Norton wanted to meet Iñárritu the next day, and once they met, Norton told him he could not cast someone who was the "embodiment" of what the script was taking aim at. Instead, the director needed to cast someone "who has at least a little bit of authentic depth of experience, in this world." Iñárritu agreed.<ref>{{cite web|title=When Norton convinced González to cast him in his film |last=Goyal |first=Samarth |date=February 11, 2015 |publisher=desimartini.com |url=http://www.desimartini.com/news/hollywood/when-norton-convinced-inarritu-cast-him-his-film/article18050.htm |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211220639/http://www.desimartini.com/news/hollywood/when-norton-convinced-inarritu-cast-him-his-film/article18050.htm |archivedate=February 11, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Ryan, one of the last actors to be cast,<ref>{{cite web|title=Amy Ryan Joins Alejandro Gonzalez-Inarritu Comedy 'Birdman' |last=Fleming Jr |first=Mike |date=March 13, 2014 |url=http://deadline.com/2013/03/amy-ryan-joins-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-comedy-birdman-452606/ |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225134059/http://deadline.com/2013/03/amy-ryan-joins-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-comedy-birdman-452606/ |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> was invited because Iñárritu had seen her in the play ''[[Detroit (play)|Detroit]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Birdman's Woman |last=Rathe |first=Adam |publisher=DuJour |url=http://dujour.com/culture/amy-ryan-birdman-interview/ |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215055655/http://dujour.com/culture/amy-ryan-birdman-interview/ |archivedate=February 15, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> [[Lindsay Duncan]] had vast experience in the theatre world too, and decided to accept the offer to play the critic because of the quality of the script. "It's delicious because of the writing."<ref>{{cite web|title=Lindsay Duncan finds her footing in 'A Delicate Balance' |last=McNulty |first=Charles |date=November 11, 2014 |work=Los Angeles Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-lindsay-duncan-delicate-balance-20141111-column.html |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WbiQESvs?url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-lindsay-duncan-delicate-balance-20141111-column.html |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no |df=mdy}}</ref> But like Shiner's character, Iñárritu found casting Laura difficult. Riseborough met him on a street corner for a cup of tea, and recalling the event, said "I told him that I would crawl across hot coals to work with him".<ref>{{cite web|title=Andrea Riseborough says 'Birdman' was like working with a theater company of actors |last=Tapley |first=Kristopher |date=October 18, 2014 |publisher=HitFix |url=http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/andrea-riseborough-says-birdman-was-like-working-with-a-theater-company-of-actors/single-page |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225134748/http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/andrea-riseborough-says-birdman-was-like-working-with-a-theater-company-of-actors/single-page |archivedate=February 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Iñárritu described Laura as "a very wacky, quirky role", but said "when [Andrea Riseborough] did it I knew that it was her, because she did it right in the tone, and she understood who she was – she was not judging".<ref name="rappler" />
===Rehearsal and filming=== [[File:Birdman6.1.13 (37).JPG|right|thumb|300px|Michael Keaton (Riggan) rehearsing an action-sequence of the film]]
Once the writing was finished, Iñárritu contacted friend and cinematographer [[Emmanuel Lubezki]] to discuss his idea for the film.<ref name="lubezki_int">{{cite web|title=Oscar-winning cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki details the 'dance' of filming 'Birdman'|last=Tapley |first=Kristopher |url=http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/oscar-winning-cinematographer-emmanuel-lubezki-details-the-dance-of-filming-birdman/single-page |publisher=[[HitFix]] |date=December 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 4, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209063303/http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/oscar-winning-cinematographer-emmanuel-lubezki-details-the-dance-of-filming-birdman/single-page |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> After reading the script, Lubezki was worried that Iñárritu would offer him the job since "[Birdman] had all of the elements of a movie that I did not want to do at all"{{snd}} comedy, studio work and long takes{{snd}} but changed his mind after further discussion with the director.<ref name="arri">{{cite web|title=Emmanuel Lubezki ASC, AMC on BIRDMAN |url=http://www.arri.de/news/news/emmanuel-lubezki-asc-amc-on-birdman/ |work=Arri News|publisher=[[Arri]]|accessdate=February 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209063314/http://www.arri.de/news/news/emmanuel-lubezki-asc-amc-on-birdman/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The pair had worked together on commercials and a short film in the anthology ''[[To Each His Own Cinema]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview: Director Alejandro González Iñárritu unmasks the 'Birdman' |last=Barta |first=Preston |publisher=[[North Texas Daily|NT Daily]] |date=October 23, 2014 |url=http://ntdaily.com/interview-director-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-unmasks-the-birdman/ |accessdate=February 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209063513/http://ntdaily.com/interview-director-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-unmasks-the-birdman/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> but not on any feature films. Lubezki wanted to be sure that this was a decision [[Rodrigo Prieto]], cinematographer of all four of Iñárritu's feature films, was comfortable with, but after receiving his blessing, the two headed into pre-production.<ref name="arri" />
Lubezki was concerned that no film had been shot in the way Iñárritu envisioned, meaning there would be no reference material to look up. The two decided the only way to learn how to shoot it would be to shoot it themselves, so they hired a warehouse in Sony Studios, Los Angeles, and built a proxy stage.<ref name="lubezki_int" /><ref name="timeout">{{cite web|title=Alejandro González Iñárritu interview: 'Everyone's terrified of being mediocre' |last=Clarke |first=Cath |url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/film/alejandro-gonzalez-inyarritu-interview-everyones-terrified-of-being-mediocre |work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]|date=October 15, 2014|accessdate=February 1, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209063729/http://www.timeout.com/newyork/film/alejandro-gonzalez-inyarritu-interview-everyones-terrified-of-being-mediocre |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The setup was minimal. Canvas and [[C-stands]] were used for walls, while tape and a few pieces of furniture marked out areas.<ref name="lubezki_int" /><ref name="desowitz">{{cite web|title=Emmanuel Lubezki on Achieving the One-Take Illusion of 'Birdman,' What's Next for Iñárritu |last=Desowitz |first=Bill |date=December 19, 2014 |publisher=Thompson on Hollywood |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/emmanuel-lubezki-on-achieving-the-one-take-illusion-of-birdman-whats-next-for-inarritu-20141219 |accessdate=February 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209064415/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/stitching-birdman-together-with-editors-douglas-crise-and-stephen-mirrione-20141017 |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Using a camera and some stand-ins, the duo worked through the movie to see if it was possible.<ref name="lubezki_int" /> Realizing no theatre could accommodate the intricate camerawork they needed, they hired [[Kaufman Astoria Studios]] in New York.<ref>{{cite news|title=Below the Line: 'Birdman' Production Design |last=Murphy |first=Mekado |date=December 31, 2014 |work=The New York Times |url=http://carpetbagger.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/31/below-the-line-birdman-production-design/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204164629/http://carpetbagger.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/31/below-the-line-birdman-production-design/ |archivedate=February 4, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Still, Iñárritu wanted to shoot at a Broadway theater, but would have to wait until several weeks into rehearsals before securing [[St. James Theatre]].<ref name="pd_int">{{cite web|title=How 'Birdman' Made A Frenzied Theater Production And Naked Times Square Trek Soar |last=Jacobs |first=Matthew |date=December 3, 2014 |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/03/birdman-production-designer-kevin-thompson_n_6221910.html |accessdate=February 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209064136/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/03/birdman-production-designer-kevin-thompson_n_6221910.html |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> They then spent a few months designing and making "blueprints" of the shots and blocking the scenes, using the stand-ins to read and walk through the script.<ref name="arri" /> The planning was precise. Iñárritu said "There was no room to improvise at all. Every movement, every line, every door opening, absolutely everything was rehearsed."<ref name="timeout" /> The actors started rehearsing once this preliminary work was completed: according to Lubezki, they did the scenes with the actors "once we kind of knew what the rhythm of the scenes were." He described the atypical approach "like an upside down movie where you do post-production before the production".<ref name="lubezki_int" />
{{rquote|left|''I know Alejandro is very adamant about kind of keeping the rabbit in the hat and not being super specific about how it was shot, but I will say it took a lot of rehearsal and it was very specific... There was no luxury of cutting away or editing around anything. You knew that every scene was staying in the movie, and like theater, this was it, this was your chance to live this scene.''|Emma Stone<ref name=atm>{{cite web |title=Birdman or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance Interview |url=http://www.abc.net.au/atthemovies/txt/s4145447.htm |work=[[At the Movies (Australian TV series)|At the Movies]] |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]|date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=January 30, 2015}}</ref>}}
Editors [[Douglas Crise]] and [[Stephen Mirrione]] were involved in the project by this stage. When Iñárritu told Mirrone that he planned for Lubezki to record table readings and the rehearsals, he suggested they edit them immediately to discover what was and was not working early on.<ref name="sd-editors">{{cite web |title=Editors Stephen Mirrione and Doug Crise on Birdman's Ultimate Disappearing Act |last=Marchant |first=Beth |date=December 17, 2014 |publisher=studiodaily |url=http://www.studiodaily.com/2014/12/stephen-mirrione-doug-crise-ultimate-invisible-edit-birdman/ |accessdate=June 29, 2015}}</ref> The editing also allowed the editors to discuss pacing issues with the director,<ref name="credits1">{{cite web |title=Invisibly Invaluable: Birdman Editors Douglas Crise & Stephen Mirrione - Part I |last=Abrams |first=Bryan |date=January 6, 2015 |url=http://www.thecredits.org/2015/01/invisibly-invaluablebirdman-editors-douglas-crise-stephen-mirrione/ |publisher=The Credits |accessdate=June 29, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629080507/http://www.thecredits.org/2015/01/invisibly-invaluablebirdman-editors-douglas-crise-stephen-mirrione/ |archivedate=June 29, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="credits2">{{cite web |title=Invisibly Invaluable: Birdman Editors Douglas Crise & Stephen Mirrione - Part II |last=Abrams |first=Bryan |date=January 7, 2015 |url=http://www.thecredits.org/2015/01/invisibly-invaluable-birdman-edtiros-douglas-crise-stephen-mirrione-part-ii/ |publisher=The Credits |accessdate=June 29, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629080721/http://www.thecredits.org/2015/01/invisibly-invaluable-birdman-edtiros-douglas-crise-stephen-mirrione-part-ii/ |archivedate=June 29, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> such as the position of the night-day transitions and other moments of rest in the film.<ref name="sd-editors" /> Production designer Kevin Thompson was on hand too, and mapped out the scenes.<ref name="pd_int" /> The camerawork required many elements of the set to be built in a certain way. For example, Riggan's makeup mirror and desk were constructed so that the camera would see his reflection.<ref name="desowitz" /> Thompson also took into consideration the needs of the crew, for instance designing the stairs a little wider for Steadicam operator Chris Haarhoff's footsize.<ref name="steadcam_int">{{cite web|title=Birdman – An Interview with Steadicam Operator Chris Haarhoff |last=James |first=Daron |date=November 26, 2014 |publisher=Sound & Picture |url=http://soundandpicture.com/2014/11/birdman-interview-steadicam-operator-chris-haarhoff/ |accessdate=February 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209064518/http://soundandpicture.com/2014/11/birdman-interview-steadicam-operator-chris-haarhoff/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> He then constructed a template of the set they would build when in New York.<ref name="pd_int" /> The writers were also involved in the rehearsals, fine-tuning the script to "make sure the film was fluid and never stopped".<ref name="SCU" />
{{Multiple image | direction = vertical |width = 180 |image1 = St James Theatre - The Producers.JPG |image2 = Kaufman Studio 35 Av 35 St sun jeh.jpg |caption2 = [[St. James Theatre]] and [[Kaufman Astoria Studios]] in New York were used to film the stage and backstage scenes of ''Birdman'' respectively.}}
Once the logistics of the scenes were worked out and they had the timing down, the team headed to Kaufman Studios for more rehearsals, followed by principal photography based exclusively in New York during the spring of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Here's How Ridiculously Difficult It Was To Film 'Birdman' In 30 Days |last=Acuna |first=Kirsten |date=October 22, 2014 |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/birdman-how-it-was-filmed-2014-10?op=1|publisher=[[Business Insider]] |accessdate= February 3, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150123232652/http://www.businessinsider.com/birdman-how-it-was-filmed-2014-10 |archivedate=January 23, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The studios were used to film the backstage areas of the film, including Riggan's dressing room and the theatre corridors. St. James Theatre was used for two weeks; it was the location for the stage scenes.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Real Comeback of the Fake Michael Keaton: Scenes From the Birdman Set |last=Brown |first=Lane |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=October 10, 2014| url=http://nymag.com/birdman-2014-9-6/ |accessdate=February 3, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065150/http://nymag.com/birdman-2014-9-6/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The bar segments were shot in The Rum House on 47th Street,<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-birdman-broadway-st-james-theatre-20141109-story.html|title = In 'Birdman,' Broadway's St. James Theatre plays itself|last = Ng|first = David|date = November 10, 2014|work = Los Angeles Times|accessdate = November 22, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209064803/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-birdman-broadway-st-james-theatre-20141109-story.html |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> and 43rd Street was used for the action-sequence.<ref>{{cite web|title=Michael Keaton films an explosive scene for 'Birdman' in NYC |last=Bord |first=Christine |date=June 4, 2013 |publisher=On Location Vacations |url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2013/06/04/michael-keaton-films-an-explosive-scene-for-birdman-in-nyc/|accessdate=February 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209064943/http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2013/06/04/michael-keaton-films-an-explosive-scene-for-birdman-in-nyc/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The film was unable to be shot chronologically because of scheduling with the theatre.<ref name="MM">{{cite web |title=True Invisibility: An Interview with Editors Stephen Mirrione and Douglas Crise of Birdman |last=Maxwell |first=Patrick |date=October 22, 2015 |publisher=[[MovieMaker]] |url=http://www.moviemaker.com/archives/interviews/birdman-editors-stephen-mirrione-douglas-crise/ |accessdate=June 29, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629080744/http://www.moviemaker.com/archives/interviews/birdman-editors-stephen-mirrione-douglas-crise/ |archivedate=June 29, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Throughout the locations, including the studio, the scenes were lit with natural light,{{efn|There was one exception, a 20K used to simulate daylight outside a window.}} since Lubezki wanted the movie "to look as naturalistic as possible." The night-time scenes were possible to film in this way due to the brightness of New York.<ref name="arri" /> Lubezki found lighting the scenes to be the hardest part of his work on the film. Not only did the lighting need to look realistic, but also had to be designed so that the continuous movements of the camera did not project the crew's shadows onto the actors.<ref name="lubezki_int" />
Throughout shooting, [[Arri Alexa]] cameras were used; an Alexa M was used for handheld sequences, and an Alexa XT was attached to the [[Steadicam]]. Neither used [[mattebox]]es, however. Steadicam operator Chris Haarhoff explained this decision: "We didn't want this big black thing gliding into their eyeline. This way we could get very close and get the light past the lens and onto the actor's face."<ref name="steadcam_int" /> Lubezki{{snd}} who did all the handheld camerawork<ref name="lubezki_int" />{{snd}} had chosen the Alexa M because the camera was very small and allowed him to get into tiny spaces and close to the actors,<ref name="arri" /> sometimes filming two inches away from Keaton's face.<ref name="desowitz" /> The camera also allowed recording for such a long period{{snd}} necessary for the long takes of the movie{{snd}} that Lubezki went so far as to say the movie would have been impossible to do years before.<ref name="arri" /> The cameras were lensed with [[Leica Camera|Leica]] Summilux-C or [[Carl Zeiss AG|Zeiss]] Master Primes.<ref name="steadcam_int" /> Lubezki stated that these gave clean images, saying "You can have all these lights in the frame and they are not really causing bad flare or things like that".<ref name="arri" /> In terms of sizes, they initially trialled a 21mm, but this did not give Iñárritu the "intimacy" he wanted. The crew instead went to an 18mm Leica, which was used for the majority of the film. Only when emphasis was needed did they switch the lens to a 14mm, but this was rare.<ref name="steadcam_int" />
Despite all the preparation, a typical shooting day would begin with rehearsals. These usually lasted most of the morning, after which photography followed.<ref name="MM" /> The meticulous timing for the scenes meant that takes were canceled because of the slightest mishaps. Emma Stone, in an interview with [[Jimmy Fallon]], recalled how a six-minute take of the scene where Riggan first meets Mike was ruined after she walked around a corner too quickly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Edward Norton Won't Talk to Emma Stone |url=http://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/segments/13766 |work=[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]] |publisher=[[NBC]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209064959/http://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/segments/13766 |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |df=}}</ref> Takes were also repeated if a scene's rhythm did not feel right to Iñárritu, or if he and Lubezki were not satisfied with a shot's framing.<ref name="lubezki_int" /> As shooting progressed lines of dialog would also be dropped, giving Iñárritu more options during post-production.<ref name="sd-editors" /> Because of this, the number of takes for a given scene was high, usually twenty for the shorter scenes,<ref name="lubezki_int" /> the takes running smoothly around the fifteenth.<ref name="steadcam_int" /> Chris Haarhoff described it as "a type of dance where everyone would hopefully try to peak all at the same moment." The locations sometimes placed restrictions on the takes too; the live Times Square sequence was shot only twice since they did not want to attract the attention of tourists.<ref name="lubezki_int" />
Whenever shooting was taking place there was pressure on everyone involved, but the cast had a positive experience. Norton said that normally in movie production half the people can "check out" due to repetitive aspects, but during the shooting of ''Birdman'' "everybody's on, the whole thing, and you're all on pins and needles because you're all relying on forty other people not to drop the ball." Because of this, Stone said the director was able to get the best out of the cast, saying "[Iñárritu's process] creates this sort of fury in you, and then you end up realizing that he just got so much out of you that you didn't even know you had".<ref name="bold" /> Naomi Watts commented that the atmosphere "felt emblematic of how it feels onstage{{snd}}at least my long-time memories from long ago".<ref>{{cite web|title=Alejandro Iñárritu's 'Birdman' is Brainy, Buoyant, Brash, Meta Moviemaking |last=Bailey |first=Jason |date=October 12, 2014 |publisher=Flavorwire |url=http://flavorwire.com/482051/alejandro-inarritus-birdman-is-brainy-buoyant-brash-meta-moviemaking |accessdate= February 4, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065010/http://flavorwire.com/482051/alejandro-inarritus-birdman-is-brainy-buoyant-brash-meta-moviemaking |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Andrea Riseborough, meanwhile, described the process as "wonderful", mentioning how it was possible to hear the filming of a sequence from far away before the camera arrived and then "the magic happens with you, and then everything leaves you, and everything's silent".<ref name="atm" /> Once they successfully completed a take though, it was obvious to everybody involved. Norton said "I've never, ever been on a set where every day ended with an enormous, authentic sort of cheer at having made it. You're waiting for the scream from [Iñárritu] and everybody was genuinely excited."<ref name="ed_and_andrea" />
===Music and soundtrack=== {{main|Birdman (film score)}} The film's original music segments are a drum score consisting entirely of solo jazz percussion performances by [[Antonio Sánchez (drummer)|Antonio Sánchez]]. The score is offset by a number of well known classical music pieces, including [[Gustav Mahler|Mahler]] and [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]]. Iñárritu did not regard the particular choice of classical pieces as important.<ref>{{cite web|title='Birdman' Score Drummed Out Of Oscars As Academy Rejects Filmmaker's Appeal |last=Hammond |first=Pete |date=December 22, 2014 |website=Deadline Hollywood |url=http://deadline.com/2014/12/birdman-out-oscars-academy-rejects-appeal-1201332029/ |accessdate=February 8, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065225/http://deadline.com/2014/12/birdman-out-oscars-academy-rejects-appeal-1201332029/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Nonetheless, the choice of classical music was strongly oriented to highly melodic scores taken predominantly from the 19th century classical repertoire (Mahler, Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninov, Ravel). Iñárritu stated that the classical components come from the world of the play, citing the radio in Riggan's room and the show itself as two sources of the music.<ref name="tohJan">{{cite web|title=Watch: Why Golden Globe Winner Alejandro González Iñárritu Took Risks on 'Birdman' |last=Thompson |first=Anne |date=January 12, 2015 |publisher=Thompson on Hollywood |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/watch-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-talks-birdman-at-telluride-exclusive-video-20140901 |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065238/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/watch-alejandro-gonzalez-inarritu-talks-birdman-at-telluride-exclusive-video-20140901 |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The classical music segments also included two compositions by American composer [[John Adams (composer)|John Adams]]. Several jazz compositions by [[Victor Hernández Stumpfhauser]] and Joan Valent counterbalance the original music composition by Sánchez. The drum sections comprise the majority of the score however, and were composed by Sánchez. Iñárritu explained the choice by saying they helped to structure scenes, and that "The drums, for me, was a great way to find the rhythm of the film... In comedy, rhythm is king, and not having the tools of editing to determine time and space, I knew I needed something to help me find the internal rhythm of the film."<ref>{{cite web|title=Watch: How 'Birdman' Composer Antonio Sanchez Drummed the Score |last=Thompson |first=Anne |date=October 13, 2014 |publisher=Thompson on Hollywood |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/watch-how-birdman-composer-antonio-sanchez-drummed-the-score-20141003 |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065326/http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/watch-how-birdman-composer-antonio-sanchez-drummed-the-score-20141003 |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Drummer-composer Antonio Sanchez talks Birdman |last=Bosso |first=Joe |date=January 28, 2015 |work=[[MusicRadar]] |url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/drums/drummer-composer-antonio-sanchez-talks-birdman-615613 |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065528/http://www.musicradar.com/news/drums/drummer-composer-antonio-sanchez-talks-birdman-615613 |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
[[File:Antonio Sanchez.jpg|right|thumb|260px|Jazz drummer [[Antonio Sánchez (drummer)|Antonio Sánchez]] composed and recorded the score for the film]]
Iñárritu contacted friend and jazz drummer Antonio Sánchez in January 2013, inviting him to compose the score for the film.<ref name="pmc">{{cite web|title=(The Unexpected Virtue Of A Jazz Drummer) |last=Malone |first=Tyler |date=Winter 2014 |publisher=PMc Publishing |url=http://pmc-mag.com/2015/01/antonio-sanchez/?full=content |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065550/http://pmc-mag.com/2015/01/antonio-sanchez/?full=content |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> His reaction to writing a soundtrack using only drums was similar to Lubezki's thoughts of shooting the movie like a single shot: "It was a scary proposition because I had no point of reference of how to achieve this. There's no other movie I know that has a score like this."<ref name="gst">{{cite web|title=Interview…Composer Antonio Sanchez on the Drums and Jazzy Ambiguity of 'Birdman' |last=Ciafardini |first=Marc |date=November 24, 2014 |publisher=goseetalk |url=http://goseetalk.com/interview-composer-antonio-sanchez-on-the-drums-and-jazzy-ambiguity-of-birdman/ |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065731/http://goseetalk.com/interview-composer-antonio-sanchez-on-the-drums-and-jazzy-ambiguity-of-birdman/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Sánchez had also not worked on a film before,<ref name="pmc" /> nevertheless, after receiving the script, he composed "rhythmic themes" for each of the characters.<ref name="ssn">{{cite web|title=Awards 2015 Spotlight: Composer Antonio Sanchez Takes SSN into the Jam Sessions that Created Birdman's Dauntless Percussion Score |last=Panosian |first=Diane |date=December 3, 2014 |publisher=SSN Insider |url=http://www.ssninsider.com/awards-2015-spotlight-composer-antonio-sanchez-takes-ssn-into-the-jam-sessions-that-created-birdmans-dauntless-percussion-score/ |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065807/http://www.ssninsider.com/awards-2015-spotlight-composer-antonio-sanchez-takes-ssn-into-the-jam-sessions-that-created-birdmans-dauntless-percussion-score/ |archivedate= February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Iñárritu was looking for the opposite approach however, preferring spontaneity and improvisation.<ref name="HF" /> Sánchez then waited until production moved to New York before composing more,<ref name="ssn" /> where he visited the set for a couple of days to get a better idea of the film.<ref name="HF">{{cite web|title=How Alejandro G. Iñárritu 'directed' drummer Antonio Sanchez's 'Birdman' score |last=Patches |first=Matt |date=November 4, 2014 |publisher=HitFix |url=http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/how-alejandro-inarritu-directed-drummer-antonio-sanchezs-birdman-score/single-page |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221062633/http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/how-alejandro-inarritu-directed-drummer-antonio-sanchezs-birdman-score/single-page |archivedate=February 21, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Following this, a week before principal photography, he and Iñárritu went to a studio to record some demos.<ref name="tohJan" /><ref name="filmxp">{{cite web|title=Birdman's Beating Heart: An Interview with Composer Antonio Sanchez |last=de Larios |first=Margaret |date=October 17, 2014 |publisher=the Film Experience |url=http://thefilmexperience.net/blog/2014/10/17/birdmans-beating-heart-an-interview-with-composer-antonio-sa.html |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209065910/http://thefilmexperience.net/blog/2014/10/17/birdmans-beating-heart-an-interview-with-composer-antonio-sa.html |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> During these sessions the director would first talk him through the scene, then while Sánchez was improvising guide him by raising his hand to indicate an event{{snd}} such as a character opening a door{{snd}} or by describing the rhythm with verbal sounds.<ref name="filmxp" /><ref name="awc">{{cite web|title=Interview: Drummer Antonio Sanchez on his first film composition 'Birdman' |last=Moulton |first=Jack |date=December 3, 2014 |publisher=The Awards Circuit |url=http://www.awardscircuit.com/2014/12/03/interview-drummer-antonio-sanchez-on-his-first-film-composition-birdman/ |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209070001/http://www.awardscircuit.com/2014/12/03/interview-drummer-antonio-sanchez-on-his-first-film-composition-birdman/ |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> They recorded around seventy demos,<ref name="ssn" /> which Iñárritu used to inform the pacing of the scenes on set,<ref name="lubezki_int" /> and once filming was complete, spliced them into the rough cut.<ref name="filmxp" /> Sánchez summarized the process by saying "The movie fed on the drums and the drums fed on the imagery."<ref name="HF" /> The official soundtrack was released as a CD (77 min) in October 2014, and as an LP (69 min) in April 2015.<ref> {{Cite web | year = 2014 | title = Birdman | publisher = Soundtrack.Net | url = http://www.soundtrack.net/movie/birdman/ | accessdate = September 16, 2015 }}</ref>
When the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] released their longlist for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Score]] in December 2014, ''Birdman'' was absent from the list. The previous day, Sánchez received a note from the award committee explaining the decision, quoting rule fifteen of the 87th Academy Award Rules, noting "the fact that the film also contains over a half an hour of non-original (mostly classical) music cues that are featured very prominently in numerous pivotal moments in the film made it difficult for the committee to accept your submission". Sánchez launched an appeal, and along with Iñárritu and the executive vice-president of [[Fox Music]], they sent letters to Charles Fox, the chair of the Academy's music branch executive committee, asking that the committee reconsider their decision.<ref name="oscar_holly">{{cite web|title=The Inside Story: Why 'Birdman's' Drum Score Isn't Eligible for an Oscar and Why an Appeal Was Rejected |last=Feinberg |first=Scott |date=December 24, 2014 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/inside-story-why-birdmans-drum-760140 |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209070310/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/inside-story-why-birdmans-drum-760140 |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> One of the points they raised was that the committee incorrectly calculated the ratio of classical to original music, which after being clarified Sánchez thought he was "on really solid ground".<ref name="HF-oscar">{{cite web|title=Exclusive: 'Birdman' composer says Oscar DQ doesn't make mathematical sense |last=Patches |first=Matt |date=December 22, 2014 |publisher=HitFix |url=http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/exclusive-birdman-composer-says-oscar-dq-doesnt-make-mathematical-sense |accessdate=February 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209070529/http://www.hitfix.com/in-contention/exclusive-birdman-composer-says-oscar-dq-doesnt-make-mathematical-sense |archivedate=February 9, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> A response from Fox on December 19 however, explained that a special meeting of the music committee was held, and although its members had "great respect" for the score and considered it "superb", they thought that the classical music "was also used as scoring", "equally contributes to the effectiveness of the film", and that the musical identity of the film was created by both the drums and classical music. Ultimately, they did not overturn their decision.<ref name="oscar_holly" /> Sánchez said that he and Iñárritu were not satisfied with the explanation.<ref name="HF-oscar" />
===Post-production and visual effects=== ''Birdman'' was edited by [[Douglas Crise]] and [[Stephen Mirrione]], who had both worked with the director before on ''[[21 Grams]]'' and ''[[Babel (film)|Babel]]''. Stitching shots together was, of course, a crucial component of the editing, but Crise and Mirrone already had experience doing this. The director had included takes that were joined together in previous films, but in these if the editors didn't think the stitching worked they had the ability to introduce cuts. Mirrone said that in ''Birdman'' Iñárritu had "let go of that safety net".<ref name="credits2" /> Because of this the editors needed to be involved in the project early on,<ref name="credits1" /> and during principal photography Crise was on set every day. (Mirrone was busy and unable to be in New York.)<ref name="sd-editors" /> Crise was not used to being on set and providing feedback, but said he was happy Iñárritu "dragged it out" of him, knowing that they wouldn't have much room to fix scenes later so they needed to get them right.<ref name="sd-editors" /> For stitching, aside from the director, Crise also discussed strategies with Lubezki and Thompson, and techniques for gluing takes together included panning on walls and actors' bodies.<ref name="deadline-editing">{{cite web |title=A Fine Frenzy |last=Bowles |first=Scott |date=October 31, 2014 |website=Deadline Hollywood |url=https://deadline.com/2014/10/editing-duo-behind-birdman-had-their-work-cut-out-for-them-864571/ |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705130643/https://deadline.com/2014/10/editing-duo-behind-birdman-had-their-work-cut-out-for-them-864571/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The editors were used to being able to adjust the rhythm of a scene by the positioning of cuts, so without this tool used Sánchez's music instead. The director gave the New York recordings to Crise early on to help with pacing, asking him to cut the music to the film. Still, in terms of the editing workflow, Crise described it as "pretty traditional". The editors cut the film together back in Los Angeles.<ref name="sd-editors" /> A few weeks after shooting they were quite far along the cut itself, and transitioned into visual-effects mode, where they fine-tuned the shots.<ref name="MM" />
<!-- Ideally an image will go here; if none are available use a good quote--> {{rquote|left|''They always talk about how when you're cutting a dance scene, a choreographer wouldn't want any cuts because she's designing something to see the whole movement, and that's what Alejandro was doing here.''|Stephen Mirrione<ref name="credits1" />}}
The visual effects for the film were created by Montreal studio [[Rodeo FX]]. They spent four months working on the film,<ref name="yvr">{{cite web |title=VFX: Rodeo FX at SPARK 2015 on Invisible VFX Behind BIRDMAN's One Continuous Shot |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=February 8, 2015 |publisher=yvrshoots |url=http://yvrshoots.com/2015/02/vfx-rodeo-fx-at-spark-2015-on-invisible-vfx-behind-birdmans-one-continuous-shot.html |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705132728/http://yvrshoots.com/2015/02/vfx-rodeo-fx-at-spark-2015-on-invisible-vfx-behind-birdmans-one-continuous-shot.html |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> and according to visual effects supervisor Ara Khanikian "visual effects touched 90% of the frames in the movie".<ref name="fxguide">{{cite web |title=Rodeo helps Birdman soar with invisible fx |last=Failes |first=Ian |date=October 28, 2014 |publisher=fxguide |url=http://www.fxguide.com/featured/rodeo-helps-birdman-soar-with-invisible-fx/ |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705132512/http://www.fxguide.com/featured/rodeo-helps-birdman-soar-with-invisible-fx/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> A lot of the work was subtle. For example, stitching shots together, or creating the background for the windows in the hospital scene.<ref name="fxguide" /> Many shots in the film feature mirrors, and much work was spent removing the reflections of the crew from these. To accomplish this the studio created a 2.5D [[Matte painting|digital matte painting]] of the reflected environment. They then [[rotoscoped]] out the parts of the mirror not containing the foreground actors and their reflections, and replaced these with the digital environment.<ref name="fxguide" /><ref name="btl-fx">{{cite web |title=The Use of VFX to Stitch Birdman Together |last=Fotheringham |first=Scott |date=February 2, 2015 |publisher=Below the Line |url=http://www.btlnews.com/awards/the-use-of-vfx-to-stitch-birdman-together/ |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705132921/http://www.btlnews.com/awards/the-use-of-vfx-to-stitch-birdman-together/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Some of the original shots captured smudges and dirt on the mirrors, so the studio developed a way to extract them so they could paste them back into the film. A matte-painting was constructed for the night-day time lapses in the film too, created by [[matchmoving]] and reprojecting shots of the buildings it features, captured at different times of the day, together.<ref name="fxguide" /> Rodeo FX also adjusted the pace of scenes. Iñárritu demanded a "very precise rhythm and flow" to the film, so the studio had to re-speed much of it with timewarp curves to fit the pacing the director desired.<ref name="fxguide" />
Unlike some of the smaller adjustments though, the flying sequence required extensive preparation. Iñárritu spent three weeks with Halon Entertainment to [[Previsualization|previsualize]] the sequence.<ref name="halon">{{cite web |title=Birdman |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |publisher=Halon Entertainment |url=http://www.halon.com/web/our-work/birdman/ |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705132932/http://www.halon.com/web/our-work/birdman/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> In New York, Lubezki then used the choreography of the previsualization to shoot background plates for the sequence,<ref name="fxguide" /> using a camera crane on a truck.<ref name="yvr" /> When these were shot, Lubezki had mounted four [[GoPro]] cameras to the lens of the film camera to capture the light environment around him. Later, on a greenstage in Montreal, using a technique he had developed on Gravity, Lubezki lit Keaton with LED panels featuring [[high-dynamic-range images]] of the surrounding New York footage. The panels then realistically lit Keaton. Khanikian described the effect of the process, saying "instead of using standard lighting on greenscreen [we were getting] the proper red bounce from the red bricks and the same color of the sky reflected on Michael's head. It worked so well." Rodeo FX then completed the final shots.<ref name="fxguide" /> The sequence was the last piece the editors inserted into the film. Mirrone commented that before the sequence was finished they "had only imagined what it was going to feel like", but once it was completed "it took the movie to this ecstatic level that absolutely blew me away."<ref name="sd-editors" />
Sound design for the film was handled by Martín Hernández, who has worked on all the director's feature films. The production sound his team was given was "surprisingly perfect and clean", so they didn't need to spend much time tidying it.<ref name="btl-sound">{{cite web |title=Contender - Sound Editor Martin Hernandez, Birdman |last=Skweres |first=Mary Ann |date=December 29, 2014 |publisher=Below the Line |url=http://www.btlnews.com/awards/contender-sound-editor-martin-hernandez-birdman/ |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705133127/http://www.btlnews.com/awards/contender-sound-editor-martin-hernandez-birdman/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The lack of visual cuts in the film meant a departure from the usual way Hernández edited sound though. "Normally Alejandro likes, as he calls it, 'the clashing of the sounds.' The camera changes angle within the scene and there is a change of everything{{snd}} backgrounds, texture, dialog. Obviously, that would not work on ''Birdman'' because here, everything is flowing."<ref name="btl-sound" /> Additionally, the sound of objects in the film needed to be coordinated with their position onscreen, a non-trivial task since the camera was nearly always moving.<ref name="btl-sound" /> Hernández also helped to cut Sánchez's tracks, selecting and editing moments from the New York recordings against the film.<ref name="morelia">{{cite web |title=Interview with Martín Hernández, 2015 Oscar Nominee |last=Alemán |first=Cristina |date=February 3, 2015 |publisher=Festival Internacional del Cine en Morelia |url=http://moreliafilmfest.com/en/como-suena-el-entorno-entrevista-a-martin-hernandez/ |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705133140/http://moreliafilmfest.com/en/como-suena-el-entorno-entrevista-a-martin-hernandez/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no }}</ref> When the tracks were re-recording in Los Angeles, in order "to have distance, and closeness and resonance" the team used thirty two microphones for each take. Hernández described the job as "crazy".<ref name="btl-sound" /> A large challenge of the post-production soundwork was designing the sound of the theatre audience, particularly in the scene when Mike is drunk and comes out of character. Iñárritu knew how he wanted the audience to respond, but figuring out the sound of their reaction took four months of work from five sound designers.<ref name="morelia" /> Hernández said he thought, for a film in general, that the narrative created by sound "provokes more 'explosions'" than that created by images, and that in ''Birdman'' "Alejandro has sound exploding all throughout the film."<ref name="morelia" />
The [[digital intermediate]] was completed by a team at [[Technicolor SA|Technicolor]] led by Steven Scott. They had previously collaborated with Lubezki on ''[[Gravity (film)|Gravity]]'',<ref name="tnclr-BM_page">{{cite web |title=Birdman |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=October 22, 2014 |publisher=[[Technicolor SA|Technicolor]] |url=http://www.technicolor.com/en/who-we-are/press-news-center/news/birdman |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705130754/http://www.technicolor.com/en/who-we-are/press-news-center/news/birdman |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> but needed to approach ''Birdman'' differently because of the continuous-shot approach. According to Scott, "we have never done anything like it before."<ref name="Scott-int">{{cite AV media |title=The Seamless Look of 'Birdman' |people=Gray, Tim (Host) |date=November 4, 2014 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XxXWs74dKnE |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705131521/https://variety.com/video/the-seamless-look-of-birdman/ |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The [[color timing]] had to be done in such a way that the transitions between color-corrected environments were invisible, in contrast to a usual film where the transitions coincide with visible cuts. To do this, the team inserted their own cuts whenever the camera was stationary, and in the middle of pans and other camera movements. They then devised a way to color correct the stationary cuts and turn the moving cuts into a form of dissolve, allowing them to "do all these independent, crazy, complicated, color corrections that would flow organically from one to another." Inserting the dissolves required [[rotoscoping]] methods which the software Scott and his team were using did not have, but an enterprise agreement between Technicolor and the software's developer led to the creation of a tool Scott required. For the color timing itself, one of the priorities of the team was making the faces as dimensional and readable as possible. This required, amongst other things, that faces be highlighted, but the moving camerawork meant that the [[Matte (filmmaking)|mattes]] used in this process had to be animated by hand. Lubezki would provide notes on the areas he wanted tracked, then the team would carry out the animations. Of the whole process, Iñárritu remarked that "everyone was out of their comfort zone", while Scott said it was the most challenging DI project of his career.<ref name="tnclr-pdf">{{cite report |title=Birdman - Case Study |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |year=2015 |publisher=technicolor |url=http://www.technicolor.com/download/file/fid/7518?file=20150213_birdman_case_study_v3.pdf |accessdate=July 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705131954/http://www.technicolor.com/download/file/fid/7518?file=20150213_birdman_case_study_v3.pdf |archivedate=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
== Analysis and themes == The director has emphasized and defended the various ambiguities intentionally included in the film: "At the ending of the film [it] can be interpreted as many ways as there are seats in the theater."<ref>{{Cite web | last = Kendrick | first = Ben | title = ''Birdman'' Ending Explained | date = April 5, 2015 | publisher = Screen Rant | url = http://screenrant.com/birdman-ending-explained-spoilers-riggan-dead/ | accessdate = September 16, 2015 }}</ref> Many aspects of [[film theory]] were debated concerning the film by critical reviews which included, among other subjects, (a) [[film genre]]; (b) intended and unresolved ambiguities of [[Plot (narrative)|plot]]; and (c) the complex interaction of Riggan's personal life with his professional life as an [[Character (arts)|actor]]. A short list of the diverse forms of film genre associated with the film has included it being referred to alternatively as a black-humor film, a mental health film, a realism/surrealism/[[magical realism]] film, a dark-humor parody film, a film of psychological realism, a failed domestic reconciliation drama, or a film concerning theatrical realism and naturalism. Inarritu has maintained his penchant, well-known to followers of his previous films, for deliberately including multiple plot lines in this film which are intentionally left unresolved at the ending.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Cowden | first = Catharina | year = 2015 | title = Birdman Ending | publisher = Cinema Blend | url = http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Birdman-Ending-Why-Obscure-Final-Shot-Makes-Total-Sense-69883.html | accessdate = September 16, 2015 }}</ref> Separate reviews in the press have also summarized the film as closely associated with the theme of the final tailspin of a late mid-life crisis in the life of a has-been actor seeking closure and resolution in his public and private life.<ref>{{cite web |first=Richard |last=Lawson |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/vf-hollywood/2014/10/birdman-review |title=Michael Keaton Struggles to Re-Invent Himself in Birdman |work=Vanity Fair |date=September 19, 2015}}</ref>
The father-daughter themes in the film, portrayed through the relationship of Riggan and Samantha, were the "most difficult" and important parts of the film to depict for co-writers Dinelaris and Giacobone, as they both had similar experiences within their families involving their own relationships with their daughters. When the writers were asked about the meaning of the ambiguous ending which the director was refusing to comment upon, they stated that any comedic ending was completely ruled out. The writers also stated that reflections about the conclusion to the film were not directly concentrated upon Riggan or the character of Birdman as much as upon the lives of the surviving characters portrayed in the film, in particular the portrayal of Riggan's daughter Samantha, rather than upon the character of Riggan himself.<ref> {{Cite web | last = Buxton | first = Ryan | title = 'Birdman' Screenwriters Discuss the Film's Ambiguous Ending | publisher = [[The Huffington Post|Huff Post Live]] | date = November 24, 2014 | url = http://live.huffingtonpost.com/r/segment/birdman-screenwriters-alexander-dinelaris-jr-nicolas-giacobone/545b966802a760ce30000262 | accessdate = September 16, 2015 }}</ref>
Noting the thematic pull between Riggan's insanity or actual superpowers, Travis LaCouter of ''[[First Things]]'' writes that "the importance of these powers{{snd}} real or imagined{{snd}} is apparent: They are for Riggan the thing beyond the labels, the kernel of his genius and, because he sees drawing upon them as selling out, the source of his great angst." LaCouter concludes that "the quirky profundity of this film is in how it dares the viewer to consider the everyday magic that we tend to ignore, repress, or resent".<ref>{{cite web|last1=LaCouter|first1=Travis|title=Birdman's Sly Metaphysics|url=http://www.firstthings.com/blogs/firstthoughts/2014/11/birdmans-sly-metaphysics|work=First Things|accessdate=September 19, 2015}}</ref>
Critics Barbara Schweizerhof and Matthew Pejkovici see the film's central theme as a satirical critique of contemporary theatrical realism, with Pejkovici laudably comparing it to Fellini's film ''[[8½]]'' (1963). As Pejkovici states: "Much like Fellini's 1960[sic] classic ''[[8½]]'', Iñárritu's ''Birdman'' is a very intimate film about an artist's malaise, yet is epic, innovative, and ambitious in approach. Iñárritu captures the artist's battle between ambition, admiration and celebrity with stunning scope and skill in the form of a one take format, as his camera sweeps through the backstage corridors, across the stage, out on the busy NYC streets, and back again in breathtaking fashion."<ref> {{Cite web | year = 2014 | title = Birdman (2014) | publisher = Matt's Movie Reviews | url = http://www.mattsmoviereviews.net/movie-critic-reviews/birdman.html | accessdate = September 16, 2015 }}</ref>
''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''{{'}}s Caryn James compared the story to that of ''[[Don Quixote]]'' (who believes himself to be a knight), as the main character believes he is a superhero (the equivalent to a knight in the 21st century).<ref name="Don Quixote">{{cite web|title=Alejandro G. Iñárritu And 'Birdman' and Don Quixote|last=James |first=Caryn |date=October 7, 2014 |work=The Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/birdman-a-film-comedy-about-a-man-and-his-ego-1412700673/ |accessdate=February 12, 2015}}</ref>
