{{Infobox book | name = White Heat | image = White heat first edition cover.jpg | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Marco Pierre White]] | illustrator = [[Bob Carlos Clarke]] | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Cookbook]] | publisher = [[Mitchell Beazley]] | pub_date = 1990 | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]) | pages = 126 pp ''(first edition)'' | isbn = 978-1-84000-343-7 | oclc = 44540505 | followed_by = Wild Food From Land and Sea (1994) }} '''''White Heat''''' is a cookbook by [[chef]] [[Marco Pierre White]], published in 1990. It features black and white photographs by [[Bob Carlos Clarke]]. It is partially autobiographical, and is considered to be the chef's first memoir. The book is cited today as having influenced the careers of several Michelin starred and [[celebrity chef]]s, and was described by one critic as "possibly the most influential recipe book of the last 20 years".<ref name=raynerquote/>
==Description== Initially published in 1990, ''White Heat'' was part [[autobiography]] of chef [[Marco Pierre White]] and part cookbook,<ref name=q&alaweekly>{{cite news|last=Scattergood|first=Amy|title=Q & A With Marco Pierre White: Escoffier, Television, Packaged Soup + The French Foreign Legion|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/squidink/2011/08/marco_pierre_white.php|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=LA Weekly|date=18 August 2011}}</ref> that portrays White's "bad boy" chef image.<ref name=womenshealth>{{cite journal|title=The Foodie: Michael Symon|journal=Women's Health|date=May 2008|volume=5|issue=4|page=6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I8YDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT10 }}</ref> White was introduced by actress [[Lowri-Ann Richards]] to her friend [[Bob Carlos Clarke]]. Clarke photographed White for a [[Levi Strauss & Co.|Levi jeans]] advert and went on to create the images for ''White Heat''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hadley|first=Kate|title=Marc and me: A year of living dangerously with TV's celebrity chef Marco Pierre White|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-498231/Marc-A-year-living-dangerously-TVs-celebrity-chef-Marco-Pierre-White.html|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=The Daily Mail|date=30 November 2007}}</ref> Speaking following Clarke's death in 2006, Marco Pierre White said, "He was like my prop. Without Bob there would never have been ''White Heat''."<ref name=tribute>{{cite news|last=Cheesman|first=Chris|title=Pierre White Show Pays Tribute to Carlos Clarke|url=http://www.amateurphotographer.co.uk/news/top_chefs_show_pays_tribute_to_carlos_clarke_news_99390.html|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=Amateur Photographer|date=2 November 2006}}</ref>
''White Heat'' is credited with changing the image of chefs to [[sex symbol]]s.<ref name=breaksmold>{{cite news|last=Rose|first=Hilary|title=Marco Pierre White Breaks the Mould|page=5|publisher=News International Trading Limited|newspaper=The Times|date=6 May 2005}}</ref> The photographs showed White in and out of the workplace, including smoking in the kitchen and working with his team,<ref>{{cite news|last=Whitworth|first=Melissa|title=Anthony Bourdain, chef and best-selling writer|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/lifestyle/7801293/Anthony-Bourdain-chef-and-best-selling-writer.html|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=3 June 2010}}</ref> including a young [[Gordon Ramsay]].<ref name=breaksmold/> One of the photographs featured White with a dead baby shark, which was laid across his lap in Clarke's garden for the shot. Clarke's wife Lindsay later said in an interview that Marco went on to gut the shark there and then in the garden, "The stench was unbelievable. I was pregnant at the time and the odour haunted me."<ref name=favouriteuncle>{{cite news|title=Bob, Chelsea girls' favourite uncle|url=http://londonersdiary.standard.co.uk/2009/05/bob-chelsea-girls-favourite-uncle.html|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=Evening Standard|date=6 May 2009}}</ref> Another photograph featured White nude with a side of [[Piglet (animal)|piglet]] in his lap.<ref>{{cite news|last=D'Souza|first=Christa|title=The Cook, his Fiancee, the Tantrums|newspaper=The Times|publisher=News International Trading Limited|date=26 July 1992}}</ref> One of Clarke's images of White was included in a set of ten donated to the [[National Portrait Gallery, London]], in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=National Portrait Gallery receives Carlos Clarke images|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-23696626|accessdate=14 August 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=14 August 2013}}</ref>
==Reception== John Lanchester, for ''The Observer'' magazine supplement ''Life'' in 2003, described the book as "gastroporn".<ref>{{cite news|last=Lanchester|first=John|title=Dear Marco The Restaurant|newspaper=The Observer Life|publisher=Guardian Newspapers Limited|date=3 October 1993}}</ref> Sue Gaisford, reviewing the book for ''The Independent'', described it as a "Marco Pierre White fanzine-with-recipes" and an "ego-trip".<ref>{{cite news|last=Gaisford|first=Sue|title=Book Review|newspaper=The Independent|publisher=Independent Print Ltd|date=18 December 1993}}</ref> In 2005 food critic [[Jay Rayner]] called ''White Heat'' "possibly the most influential recipe book of the last 20 years".<ref name=raynerquote>{{cite news|last=Rayner|first=Jay|title=The Man with the Dough|newspaper=Observer Food Monthly|publisher=Guardian Newspapers Limited|date=10 July 2005 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2005/jul/10/foodanddrink.features12}}</ref>
==Legacy== ''White Heat'' is credited as being the first chef [[memoir]],<ref name=q&alaweekly/> and has been cited as influencing the future careers of [[Michelin star]]red chefs, including [[Sat Bains]] and [[Tom Kerridge]],<ref>{{cite news|title=TV chefs 'encourage boys to cook'|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/276035-tv-chefs-encourage-boys-to-cook|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=Metro}}</ref><ref name=mylifeinfood>{{cite news|title=My life in food: Tom Kerridge|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/features/my-life-in-food-tom-kerridge-6285538.html|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=6 January 2012}}</ref> and [[celebrity chef]]s [[Curtis Stone]] and [[Jean-Christophe Novelli]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet Curtis Stone|url=http://tlc.discovery.com/fansites/takehomechef/bio.html|publisher=TLC|accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Chloe|title=Cooking up a storm at Christmas|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/food/802463-cooking-up-a-storm-at-christmas|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=Metro|date=1 December 2009}}</ref>
''[[The New York Times]]'' published an article on 13 May 1998 describing White's career, using a passage from ''White Heat'' to say that the chef had a "well-publicized bout with drugs and alcohol".<ref name=nyteditor>{{cite news|title=Editors' Note|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/16/nyregion/editors-note-875465.html?src=pm|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=16 September 1998}}</ref> It published an apology to the chef regarding this statement later that year on 16 September, describing the passage it had used from the book as "ambiguous".<ref name=nyteditor/> The passage described White going on a drink and drugs "[[Binge drinking|bender]]",<ref name=drinksbender/> something that White later denied in court during the libel case, saying that he did not proof-read his books as he is [[dyslexic]].<ref name=drinksbender>{{cite news|last=Fisher|first=Lorraine|title=Marco: I Didn't go on Binge|page=15|newspaper=The Daily Mirror|publisher=Mirror Group|date=5 April 2000}}</ref>
White's first appearance on the television show [[Hell's Kitchen (UK TV series)|''Hell's Kitchen'']] in 2007 caused the price of second-hand copies of his old cookbooks to spike. ''White Heat'' had been seen as a collector's item, but after the television show, the price increased to as much as £250 for a signed first edition.<ref>{{cite news|last=Muir|first=Jenny|title=Collectable food books|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/books/features/3829/Collectable_food_books.html|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=Time Out|date=13 November 2007}}</ref> In 2008 it was recommended by television chef [[Michael Symon]], writing for ''[[Women's Health (magazine)|Women's Health]]'', despite being out of print in America at the time.<ref name=womenshealth /> [[Arthur Potts Dawson]] described it as a "rock'n'roll cookbook" in an interview with ''[[The Independent]]'' in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Montgomery|first=Hugh|title=Arthur Potts Dawson: 'I love fudge, but my teeth are wrecked because of it'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/features/arthur-potts-dawson-i-love-fudge-but-my-teeth-are-wrecked-because-of-it-6284835.html|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=8 January 2012}}</ref>
